reviewText:
I must say this is the most unique and engrossing games I have played in quite some time. The game forces you to slow down and look for clues in order to solve the array of mysteries that you undertake. Having a keen eye and a good memory is imperative to cracking the case. The interrogations are truly the most gripping part of the game; nothing is more exciting than getting a confession after spending hours unearthing clues, following leads, interviewing witnesses and chasing suspects.

Team Bondi has changed the face of video games with L.A. Noire. The facial expressions in this game are unrivaled by anything currently out there, and they're not just used during cut-scenes, it's in effect at all time during the game; a level of dedication most becoming of a Rockstar Game. They're so good in fact that you're left wanting the rest of the world to be on par. I'm not saying that it looks bad but it is missing minor polish seen in other Rockstar games (I understand it's a Bondi game...) like limited damage on the cars, bullet holes are missing when a car or person is shot... and that's it. That's all the nitpicking I can pull off.

Gunplay isn't as sharp as Grand Theft Auto and takes a little getting used to but it feels right for this type of game and works just fine. The focus isn't wholesale gunfights, rather poignant, key engagements that mean something; you are an officer of the law after all.

Give this game a shot if you like cop dramas, film noires, GTA, tacos, fresh and unique gaming experiences.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a detective game, simple as that. If you're looking for another shoot everything rampage game like GTA just because this game is made by Rockstar then this is not the game for you. Sure there is shooting, but you won't be allowed to kill everyone in sight, running people over will affect your case rating etc.

The Atmosphere
Personally, I love the setting of the game, the late 40s jazz theme mixed with golden age Hollywood as well as a classic noir feel makes for a great mix, but while the storytelling is good, it's not all there. The story feels a bit like it's jumping around without finishing everything off, Rockstar gathered enough story for a movie, but not a 20 hour game. Because of this you will be left with extra things that feel like they are just there to fill up an hour of your time and parts of the story that are never properly concluded. This being said, the story has some great parts towards the second half of the game and does a great job 80% of the time, however the ending will feel incomplete.

Gameplay and Fun
It's fun to drive around and using your siren to move people out of the way is great. The car chases are exciting at first but end up being repetitive, as with all the chases. Shootouts feel this way too and there are one or two that will feel boring. The combat tends to feel stiff from time to time. For an open world game it is very linear and the free roam mode itself actually takes some working out to access. Street crimes are fun to attend to and interrogations are challeging. The clue finding in the game is brilliant and walking around the crime scenes never gets old although you will quickly work out the set structure to finding all the clues.

Sound
The sound in the game makes for great immersion, no complaints here really. The hint sounds at crime sounds can be turned off if they make the game too easy and the whole feel of the sirens and the radio really sells the 40s atmosphere.

Graphics
The facial expressions are the best part about the graphics, I didn't notice too many hiccups in the graphics and if I did they didn't distract from the game. The faces of people look incredibly lifelike and all the other graphics are good too. The sunny setting of Los Angeles adds a bright feeling to the game.

Replayability
While you do have the option to replay your cases to get all clues and perfect your interrogation this game is likely to be one you will only play the story of once, it's still fun to drive around and do street crimes but the cases tend to be something that's best as a one time thing.

Verdict
Overall this game is great fun and a nice step away from GTA while still keeping to the Rockstart format. It feels fresh but also familiar. The graphics look very good for a game that came out in 2011. You will feel very immersed in the time period through use of sound and surroundings. The open world side has something to be desired and Los Angeles doesn't exactly feel as alive as GTA 4's Liberty City or Watch Dog's Chicago, it doesn't have much of a personality, the characters do. If you're looking for a good open world game, this isn't it, if you're looking for a good story with a mix of puzzle and regular shoot/drive gameplay and well designed characters then this is it.

Get this if:
You like a good story
You want diverse gameplay that makes you think
You like the Noir settingDon't get this if:
You want full freedom in an open world
You want to go on a killing spree
You don't care about story  8.5/10

reviewText:
TL;DR? See Conclusion
INTRODUCTION:L.A. Noire is an open world neo-noire police / detective game made by Team Bondi and published by Rockstar Games. It features crime scene investigation, interrogations, arrests, and possibly, for the first time in the Rockstar games portfolio, police chases where the player is the police.

If you like movies such as L.A. Confidential (specially this one), Chinatown and The Untouchables, you'll definitely might want to give this game a try.

PROS:+ Facial Animation: -The selling point of L.A. Noire is possibly the facial motion capture technology that was employed. It is this technique that makes the game's interrogations as close to realism as possible for the 'truth / doubt / lie' mechanic to work.

+ Atmosphere: -The devs have done remarkable work recreating the wonderful city of 1947 Los Angeles. Although it may not be exactly how it was back then, it's still a large and magnificent city to explore. From the cars, the clothing, the buildings and the radio, Team Bondi certainly nailed the 1947 atmosphere.

+ Investigation: -From examining clues to following leads, LA Noire delivers a great police / detective mechanic that provides fun and exciting experience.

+ Sound: -Great voice acting, great selection of 1940s classic hits, a bit of radio news from that time, good sound effects and some very classical OST vibe. The voice acting makes for some very memorable characters with unique personalities.

+ Playtime: -The game is extensive and will require some time to finish. From the main story, DLC cases, Street Crimes and Collectibles, there are a lot of things to do which is more than enough to make you feel that your money was well spent.

CONS:- 30 FPS: -According to the devs, the reason for this was that the motion-capture technology would not function properly if it was not locked at 30 FPS. Be that as it may, most PC gamers would still expect certain games to run at 60fps minimum.

- Awkward Body Movements: -I kinda feel they focused a bit too much on the facial animation and severely under developed the body animation. Most character movements are awkward and the bodies seem to move like they were made from cardboard or cement.

-  No reward for Non-Lethal Arrest: -The game has optional 'Street Crimes' which can be solved by lethal or non-lethal methods (depending on the Crime). Unfortunately, there is no reward in trying to chase down a fleeing suspect and it would be much easier just to shoot them in the back. This disappointed me a lot.

CONCLUSION:GOOD GAME for a GOOD PRICE. L.A. Noire captures the classical 1940-70 police / detective movies that once graced the silver screens but with a bit of modern sprinkles to it.

WORTH IT?:Sale or full price, this game is worth every penny.

I suggest that potential buyers of this game purchase the 'Complete' Edition which includes the DLCs because they extend the gameplay by providing additional 'Cases' for each of the game's chapters.

reviewText:
I have enjoyed this tremendously. This is probably the most expensive adventure game ever created, only without the point-and-click, of course. But you will be going from location to another location and looking for clues.

You will scoff at the locked 30 fps and you'll be baffled at the confusing interrogations, however the atmosphere and the authenticity of this game is a marvellous feat. Los Angeles depicted in the late 40s is only a backdrop, but it plays its role well.

Playing L.A. Noire was like watching a really great TV series – each case is around an hour and a half long, and they all tell a different story. If this were a film, it would be quite bland probably, but this is game, and with interactivity it comes to life. Also I have to say the face capture technology is not a gimmick but an integral part of gameplay, and I cannot wait for the next game by Team Bondi and Mr. McNamara.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is not for everyone, it's linear, you gotta make the right decisions or most of the time you'll see a game over screen.
But for those who, like me, are into detective whodunit type of stories this game is for you.
There's content here for all tastes in crime: traffic, vice, arson and the Homicide desk, which is the best IMO.
The driving feels a bit stiff, but nothing that will bother you too much, since you can have your partner drive you places if you don't feel like spending time behind the wheel and want to get straight to business.
There is quite some replay value if you want to discover all clues, get all the film reels, cars etc..

*The producers really put some hard work in bringing 1947 Los Angeles back, the city is beautiful and feels alive, like every person walking the streets has a story to tell, the attention to detail in this game is amazing, its a pity that so many areas of the city are left out of the main story.

Needless to say I recommend this game for those who are interested in deep narrative and focus on story rather than just mindless action.

reviewText:
This is one of the best detective games I've ever played. L.A Noire is also very underrated compared to other games from Rockstar Games. Only problem with this game is the PC-port. The resolution was a little strange on my computer and unfortunately the game is locked at 30 fps. That basically means that it runs and looks  like the console version. I would actually recommend an xbox 360 controller to get the best experience.

You play as Cole Phelps, a police officer. As the story goes you get higher and higher rank. You move up from a police officer to Arson Desk, Vice Desk and so on. You solve big murder cases by finding clues and interview witnesses. The story is good and comes with a plot twist and a surprising ending. The notable thing about L.A Noire is the Motion Scan though. It is a really cool technique where you use multiple cameras to capture facial expressions from every angle. It looks so real, and I wish more games would use this. In L.A Noire they used 32 cameras just for the face.

The biggest problem with the FPS-cap is when you're driving. The driving feels slow and laggy. However, the framerate wasn't a problem when I investigated things, and that's what you will do the most. You can have your partner drive to almost all locations (like a fast travel) which is great and prevents the problem. So if you're thinking about buying this game for the driving then I would say no, buy GTA instead. If you want a good action adventure crime game, then this is for you.

It's tough to decide whether I should recommend this game or not. It's such a great concept with good gameplay, superb voice acting and Motion Scan, but the PC-port is far from good. I think LA Noire is too good to miss out on just based on the port though, so I would say i recommend it. Pick it up on sale and you shouldn't regret it. I got 45 hours of enjoyment just from the story, and I still have many side activites to do.

reviewText:
There are games you know when you play that there hasn't been any real work put into it and most of the budget went into marketing. But there are some games that when you play, you KNOW that the sheer amount of creativity put into it and the expenses made to craft the experience and make a world has paid off.

And then there's LA Noire.

This game sets a new standard for the storytelling experience in games, not only with it's technology, but with it's excellent integration of good gameplay mechanics and using that as a way to unravel for yourself the world and it's mysteries.

The gameplay involved in solving the cases is pretty solid, with you scouting for clues that will later be used in interrogations. Though the clue-hunting is little more than a game of click-everywhere-until-something-happens, the meat is in the driving sequences and the interrogations. The driving sequences make full use of the fact that there's a big open world out there and anything could happen. Simply driving from one place to another is a nice experience as you see in full glory the love and patience with which Team Bondi recreated 1940s LA. Of course these can be skipped but you'll be missing out on the side missions which dot the city from time to time and can only be discovered if you take over the wheels.

But the true flavor comes from the interrogations. They used this technology masterfully in order to not only make the interrogations engaging, but also accessible with some exaggerations on the part of the actors which was done on purpose knowing full well the limitations this technology could have. Simply reading the expressions isn't enough since you also have to back up your accusations with evidence. This requires some thought and patience on your part and you need to read the descriptions of each clue carefully before using them. Suffice it to say that the game is worth it for these sequences and there are a LOT of them.

The story too is quite excellent with many noire elements, plot twists and an overarching conspiracy. LA Confidential, the 1997 movie set in around the same time, was a considerable influence for the game.

There are a few negatives though. Some cases felt like I wasn't really solving them. Even though ALL the cases have definitive culprits, there were a couple of cases where I felt I was simply going through the motions. The shooting isn't very good. The chase sequences on foot aren't really great as there are some navigation issues. Though the game is HUGE with MANY cases and the DLC also contributing to the list, there's not much to do outside the story missions which somewhat ruins the fact that these guys toiled so much to recreate this beautiful city. The PC port, though it has many of the features other PC ports lack like a good options menu and reasonable mouse support, it still is quite wonky though I wasn't too distracted by it.

Minor faults don't bring down this excellent game though. It is something I would definitely recommend to any gamer who wants to play a linear story-driven non-action intensive game. Suffice it to say that after I was done, I missed the game and felt just a little hollow inside.

reviewText:
Review for L.A. Noire

Pros :
- Awesome Playable Character
- Strong Story
- Amazing Face Animations

cons :
- 30FPS Lock on PC
- Games looks outdated.

Review :

In L.A. Noire you play as Cole Phelps, War Veteran Who fought in the Second world war in The American army in Japan.
After the war returned to Los Angeles he starts to work as a Cop, but after proving himself, he becomes a Detective...
In the game your main goal is to solve cases as good and as truly as possible...
in a City filled iwth Corruption and shady Characters...

One of the things you will be doing alot in this game is Looking around, looking for clues.
Interrogating people is also a big part of the game, Here is where the Face Animations play a big role...
it can be really hard to see if someone is lying or telling the truth.

Knowing this is a Rockstar game doesn’t mean its a shooting game or something like GTA
you're not allowed to just randomly kill people on the street or to carry a gun when you want.
As a LAPD Detective your job is to protect the people of Los Angeles.
There also isn't a Open world to this game, While doing mission you can have little sub mission in them,
i noticed when i was driving to my next location some random event could happen on the streets, and its my choice to do something or just keep driving.
this give it alot of replay value and just changed the passing abit.

Overall I really enjoyed this game, and i clocked 21 hours in my first Play
I also felt pretty sad and empty when the game ended.

Hope L.A. Noire 2 is on its way.

Release date : 20th of may 2011
Developer : Team Bondi,  Rockstar North,  Rockstar San Diego,  Rockstar Leeds,  Rockstar New England,  Rockstar Lincoln.
Publisher : Rockstar Games.
Category : Singleplayer
Website : http://www.rockstargames.com/lanoire/

reviewText:
Presentation

L.A. Noire has an excellent setting, Los Angeles in the 1940's, and everything the game has to offer feels very true to this setting.

The story of the game is very well written, offering insight to life in the 1940's overall as well as focusing even more on the lives of cops, crooks, and war veterans.

Graphics

L.A. Noire's graphics are excellent. Even though the game's a few years old by now, it still looks spectacular, and nothing in the game is boring to look at.

All the animations look great and it's worth to note that there haven't been better facial animations in video games after this game.

Sound

From the sound effects to the songs and shows on the car radio as well as the music that's been carefully selected to feel right in different situations, everything in this game sounds just right.

Gameplay

There are gameplay elements that will instantly feel very familiar to those who've played any of Rockstar's games before. But there are also many unique features that this game has to offer.

The game is divided into different cases during which the players are also able to focus on different side quests like dealing with street crimes and finding different cars and landmarks.

Questioning the suspects and other people of the world is done very well. Although, I have to say that on a few occasions, I felt that the right choices were a bit surprising to say the least.

Noteworthy

My playtime of 38 or so hours includes just one playthrough with all the DLC cases included. I also did over half of the street crime missions and unlocked more that a third of the vehicles the game had to offer.

I did come across a few bugs during my playthrough, but they were mostly graphical stuff that disappeared fairly quickly. I also experienced some stuttering every now and again, and the game did freeze two or three times during the almost 40-hour long playthrough. However, I feel that these had little impact to how much I enjoyed the game itself.

The game does require for the player to log in to a Rockstar Social Club account, but it is possible to choose a Default" account for which the player doesn't have to provide any personal information and which requires no email verification or the like."

reviewText:
Essentially LA Confidential: The Video Game. The similarities between the two are remarkable, although I'm guessing most of the inspiration originates from the books the movie was based on. LA Noire is not without its problems, but if you approach it thinking it's more like an interactive movie than a video game, you'll probably enjoy it. It just oozes atmosphere and setting. The acting is really good, and due to the incredible facial animations it's not just voice acting that you're watching.  You'll probably recognize various actors from other roles they've played (mostly on TV). It's really like nothing else I've experienced in a video games.

The problem is the gameplay. There's a few parts to it: finding clues, questioning/interrogating witnesses and suspects, and fighting/driving. Finding clues isn't all that bad, although it can get kind of tedious. Questioning people is the fun part, as you have to pay attention to character's facial expressions (that originate from the actual actor that played the part). The combat, however, is pretty bad. It's clunky, shallow, and repetitive. Fortunately, it's not a major part of the game, so it's bearable.

Overall, if you want to enjoy gritty, noire detective stuff, this game is for you.

reviewText:
What a frustrating and disappointing game.

The most basic flaw with the game is the poor and inconsistent logic that's used to govern interrogations, which is the game's primary mechanic and conceit.

Interrogations work like this: you ask a witness or suspect about a topic, and he gives a response, at which point you have to choose between three options to characterize that reply -- Truth, Doubt, or Lie. If you choose Lie, you must select a piece of evidence that contradicts the interviewee's statement. A correct choice nets you experience and possibly a new clue or lead, while a failure may shut down the rest of the interrogation.

The problem is that sometimes you will have evidence that suggests a person is lying, but the game expects you to choose Doubt instead. Other times, the game expects you to accuse the interviewee of lying in cases where you're not calling out a specific lie, or where the evidence that the game wants you to use to substantiate the accusation does not clearly contradict the interviewee's lie.

Here is an example; I'll be a little vague and change some names and details so it shouldn't be too much of a spoiler:

Towards the end of a case, I was in a room with a crook that we'll call Tony. In Tony's office I found some clues, including some forged documents that was noted as having come from a corrupt businessman that I'll call Levy, as well as hard evidence that Tony had leverage over Levy. Also worth noting is that I had interviewed Levy earlier, and Levy's records helped lead me to Tony's location.

During my interview with Tony, my character asked for information about co-conspirators -- this is apparently so you can learn about Levy, in case the player has not already encountered him in the course of the investigation. Tony stonewalls, saying he acted alone. To me, the correct response to this would be to call him out on the lie, and cite either the forgeries (which is noted as being Levy's work), or the evidence that shows that Tony has leverage over Levy (though it's really both of these pieces of evidence COMBINED that make Tony's lie obvious). But no, the correct" response is to Doubt
date: which gets Tony to give up Levy as co-conspirator.\n\nIn the follow-up question to that
recommended: my character asked who Levy is and where I can find him. This is completely stupid as my character had already interviewed Levy and knows exactly where he is. The stupidity is then compounded when Tony claims that Levy is one of the gangsters I shot dead on my way in to Tony's office. However
hoursPlayed: as a player I couldn't think of any evidence I could cite that contradicts that absurd lie ("the fact that I know Levy's face" is not a selectable piece of evidence in my notebook) so I selected Doubt. Wrong answer. Apparently

reviewText:
L.A Noire Review

Information

Game - L.A Noire
Publisher - Rockstar Games
Developer - Team Bondi
Release Date - 17th May 2011
Genre - Action/Adventure
Trading Cards - None
Achievements - yes(60)
When i first saw this game at the store i wondered wether it's gonna be worth it,Rockstar games famous for making games like GTA,Manhunt and Red Dead Redemption gonna make a cop game!? It was a change from their usual games and quite a brave move.I thought this was gonna be a game nobody would remember,but boy was i wrong...

Categories        Details                Story        In LAN you play as an LAPD cop and later detective named Cole Phelps a former war hero in WW II. LAN is set in the Los Angeles of 1947 which has been created beautifully.In the game you start up as a cop and later get promoted due to your notable breakthroughs.At first it seem LAN has no story and it's just random cases which you have solve but later on as you proceed you unravel a story of army surplus Morphine racketeering and land bussiness scam which has Cole personally involved as his former army freinds are being murdered.It also features many sub-plots and also shows past incidents of Cole's life in the army which forms a major part of the  plot. The game's story is very well told,the way each case in the later part of the game coincides with the plot revolving around the protagonist is wonderful.The cases which are not related to the main plot are very well told as well and most of them are inspired from real life crimes which kinda gives you creeps when you play the missions featuring gruesome murders.
The voice acting and facial acting is very well done as well. Yes i said facial acting. Team Bondi has used some technology using multiple cameras and used the real expressions of the actors in the game which along with good voice acting adds to the atmosphere. When the characters talk you feel like they are real people.It is one great feature of L.A Noire.

SCORE: 9/10                 Gameplay        The gameplay of LAN is simply unique.The gamplay ranges from gun fights,melee fights,foot chase,car chase,tailing missions(both in car and foot),driving cars,puzzle solving(riddles and stuff)investigating clues,interrogation.You play the game as a cop and paly through various departments. You start the game as a patrol man then get promoted to be a detective at the traffic department,then to homicide then vice and finally arson.The best missions are the one in homicide and vice.

The game's uniqueness lies in it's clue finding and interrogation.In the interrogation you question your witness and when you are answered by the suspect, you must determine wether he/she is telling the truth or lying. You are given three options in this mater, 1st option is truth which you select if you think the suspect is telling the truth,2nd option is doubt which you choose when you think your suspect is lying but don't have any proof and the 3rd is lying when you think your suspect is lying and you have proof to back up your charge.You may wonder how to determine wether your suspect is lying or not well it's by studying the expression of the suspect.As I told you earlier the technology used in this game is unique and the real expression of the actors are used. When people lie they make all sorts of silly expression(susupicious) and when telling the truth they look straight faced.If you accuse a person the of lying make sure you have got proof and from the clues listed in your notebook you have to choose the correct ones as selecting the wrong one will get that question wrong.Though making mistakes won't totally fail the case but getting less than half the questions on the case right fails the mission.Passing the missions is not the only aim,you are even rated from between 1-5 stars,the more stars you get the more salary you earn.Detucting these truth-lie mechanisms are sometimes easy and sometimes hard.You have to stay attentive in order to get the correct clues to branch to the questions. Wether they ae lying or not is mostly easy as while lying the actors make silly suspicious faces,selecting the real clue is a challenge.
As this is a cop game you cannot always carry around your gun on the streets and use it,they can only be used during gun fights.
Driving mechs are simillar to that of the GTA games and you can take any car on the street and drive it,only this time you don't punch people on the face but show off your batch take the car saying you need it for upholding justice.Driving is pretty easy but don't expect to see Lambourghinis as this is set in the 40's.
The game has side missions in the form of street crimes that is crimes that have sprung up immediately and the crime is still in the act where you have to respond quick,it can be chasing the criminals or fighting them.
The puzzles and riddles are very well done as well, most of them really challenge your brain while some are very easy.
Open world is not directly in the main game(as u r actually solving a case at the beginning of all cases) but from the menu you can select the free world mode and play it but there is nothing of much interest.

Crashing cars and damaging properties will affect you rating and minus your salary(though they are of no use in the game).Killing people while driving be penalised as you fail the mission in doing so.

Though it has got some unique feature palying LAN at a stretch might get boring.

SCORE: 9/10                  Graphics        The graphics of LAN are mordern considering the date of release of the game(2011) and are sweet to the eyes even now(2015).This graphics quality along with the facial feature technology used in this game for the first time in video gaming history is awesome. The city of Los Angeles of 1940's looks beautiful and is realistic(even features racialy biased cops),It really feels like your are in the LA of 1947.

SCORE: 9/10
L.A Noire is a great game for all lovers of adventure and action and suspense story and noire theme lovers and every gamer(until you r a hard core COD fan who feels that COD deserves GOTY).The game is really well done and is worth every penny.Also get the DLC bundle of this game(which i had,and it gives you extra missions).Playing LAN made me feel like a real detective.Go get it,it's a must have in your library.

Overall:9/10

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [ http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText: I would kill for a new LA Noire
voteText: 25 of 27 people (93%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
LA Noire is a rather interesting title. It's a Rockstar game but it was developed by an Australian developer named Team Bondi. Why this is relevant is many of the developers from Team Bondi made an eerily similar game called The Getaway which also focused on cinematic action.

LA Noire is unlike the Grand Theft Auto games it gets compared to. A big focus of the game is it's cinematics and it's interrogation mechanic. Where the player is required to tell if a character is lying or not. While I would say it was implemented fairly well, unfortunately the developers confuse you every so often with the range of options. Sometime a suspect isn't lying but rather just not telling enough information. And instead of selecting lie you're supposed to select doubt". Thankfully the developers also implemented a lifeline style mechanic where you can ask the community what the most commonly selected responses are.

While I would say LA Noire was an excellent game unfortunately it was an imperfect one. The game starts out exceptionally well and the quality of the writing stays consistant until the middle. After the homicide desk the writing begins to get worse and worse
date: to the point when you get to the ending you begin laughing at how ludicrous the entire thing is. I wouldn't say the experience isn't worthwhile but don't go into this expecting it to be Red Dead Redemption levels of satisfaction.\n\nIt's unsurprising to find out this game had two entire desks cut (of which 4 remain in the final release) considering the storyline remains just a little half baked. It's unfortunate to see with such an ambitious game
recommended: but since it was in development for 8 years it's surprising that it came out at all."

reviewText:
It's been almost a year since I wrote something up here. But well, everybody is at some point back where he started, so I figure it out, why just don't write up the review for a game, which is in my personal TOP 10. Right ?

When I look back, and check all the products, that Rockstar Games has put out, I'm not even sure if I'm able to name at least one, which was average or even under that. Man .... they even did a fantastic movies, didn't they ?

When they try to make open world game, it's understandable that comparision with Grand Theft Auto is not anything bad.  Red Dead Redemption v. GTA. / Bully v. GTA. / The Warriors v. GTA (My lord, The Warriors are even better than GTA in some way) / and also Midnight Club for some reason. And there comes the L.A. Noire. New genre that R* step a foot in, and got out as a king again and again and again.

L.A. Noire is as you of course know the detective game set in 40s Los Angeles. You can compare this to Sherlock Holmes games, and Cole Phelps will be still better detective. Story is so gripping that one case might drives you crazy, and then you realize that Rockstar is just master of art in the gaming world.

There is one thing, that I also realized during the exploration of LA which is really huge and more realistic than GTA V would ever be. However, the developer itself pretty doesn't give a flying f*ck if people discover beautifulness inside. I am talking about hidden spots and interesting places all over the Los Angeles. It's pretty usual that some devs puts spots out to player to see them. R* is not doing that way. They put tons of spots, and hide them even more than usually.

This game is filled with landmarks, and especially golden film reels which are pretty difficult to spot. Thing is, that even after discovering 30 of various world-famous places and 50 hidden golden films, you can go further, explore on your own, and discover spots that wasn't made for casual player, but for true explorer. I've been to LA this year, and I must say, that a lot of places that are shown in this game, looks practically same (not just landmarks, also the standard streets at some point) no matter the time game is set was more than 70 years ago.

I've talked a lot about the town, but I have to be honest with you, but town is most enjoyable thing for me personally in the game. More than the characters, more than Cole and more than the story and cases.

More than 20 cases ready for you (which lenght of the one might be easily above 40 mins) 40 side street crimes, and enormous spots to discover for you. Great thing was, that besides the main story line, there was a lot of different stories going all way along and meet each other in the end.

I've got to tell you much more, but I will leave it. I don't want this review to be another Saints Row 3 review of mine :X

10/10

reviewText:
This is the best detective game on Steam at the moment. You play as Cole Phelps, a veteran who went into police work in order to keep serving his country and dispense justice. As you play, you say to hell with procedure and take the initiative to solve the crimes the lazy detectives are glossing over. This gets you promoted to become a full-time detective, and you make your way up the hierarchy of crime investigators.

I'm not gonna bother dividing these things into pros and cons. If you need a detective game in your life, buy it.
If you don't, read this review and buy it.


GAMEPLAY:
You're not buying the game for this:
- This is a third person open world game, yet it has nearly nothing to find or do in terms of free roaming. Between missions you may accept a street crime side mission, but they often boil down into a chase, a car chase or a shoot-out, all of which probably won't get your blood pumping. Do yourself a favour and just follow the story; it's pretty long.
- The combat is boring and generic. The weapons bear no real feeling of impact and you can take a lot more bullets than the bad guys. Melee combat is practically unexistant. The combat is merely a way of prolonging the game and supplement the story.
- No reward or change if you decide to go for a non-lethal arrest.
- The driving is nothing spectacular. It's far less enjoyable than in most Rockstar games in that it's pretty slow and car chases force you into just trying to keep the driver in sight until the game decides that he's arrived at his final destination. Occasionally you will be able to have your partner shoot out the suspect's tires, which feels alright, but you won't be aiming.
- Interrogation is a pretty fun mechanic which is probably what this game is known for. You have to read the suspect/victim's facial expressions and pick up on uncertainty or curious claims, then decide if they're lying or telling the truth and reveal more info/clues if you answer correctly. Sometimes you'll be dealing with good liars that the game won't tell you about, who tell you their side of the story very rigidly and confidently, but without the facts adding up. This is to make sure you know have an overview of the case and it's a very nice touch.
- Facial features and animations are great, since a fairly thorough facial motion capture method was used for every character and gels very well with the story. As a result, every character in the game looks like the person who performed the voice.
- The game is locked to 30 FPS for the facial motion capture to work.

STORY:
The reason this game is nothing short of phenomenal:
- Between cases, you will sometimes get a clip that goes back to Cole's participation in the war in Japan after the attack on Pearl Harbour. From the very beginning of the game, you'll be seeing these clips/flashbacks and they will play into the story as you progress. The way the game creates parallel story lines that eventually cross into eachother is absolutely fantastic.
- The cases are often connected to eachother in some way; I can't say much without spoiling it.
- They're also fairly devoid of plot holes and create a comprehensive and complete experience.
- The job eventually expands into your personal life, even though it initially doesn't seem like you even have one.
- Characters from the story occassionally appear in the side missions (street) crimes, which is a nice touch but it won't mean or matter much.
- The atmosphere is extremely immersive and convincing; when you launch this game, you turn into L.A.'s top detective in a realistic city based on real places with real landmarks.
The music amplifies the detective noir vibe and is probably the final aspect that gets you into the role.
Every character wears clothes and sets their hair in a way that is true to the time period as well.
- The voice acting is absolutely beautiful and convincing in every aspect. Team Bondi really scratched together some very talented people.

L.A. Noire does what is does very well, and as long as you're willing to look past the FPS cap and just follow the main story line, you will be an experience richer.
The interrogation mechanic might get dull after a while; for this I recommend you consider what you'd answer in a situation and then look up the correct answer in a guide to keep you trekking along.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is about a detective named Cole Phelps that worked in post-WW2 late 1940s Los Angeles. Gameplay is open world and consists entirely of interviewing/interrogating people, chasing suspects with cars/on foot, shootouts with criminals, and walking around crime scenes or area of interest to find clues and evidence. This is a pretty unique game since it's made by Rockstar, which is well-known as the creator of GTA. You get to be the good guy this time, including chasing & ramming cars that will be ended with you busting the suspect GTA-Style (remember Busted scene in GTA? you're the cop here).  Even with obvious low-budget graphics, the story was very well made and the characters expressions (face and voice) are EXTREMELY 'alive' compared to other games. This is because you get to judge whether someone is lying or not by facial expression/voice tone. Ah, if you're a classic car lover, this game paid a lot of attention to them. In short, L.A. Noire is a very out-of-the-box interesting detective game that is definitely worth the price.

Now let's talk about the good things first. I'm no policeman and I have no experience in any police work, but I dare to say that with a huge amount of available cases and side missions, the game will definitely satisfy your thirst of 'problem solving' or 'mystery' or straight out 'detective work'. I definitely can't say it's realistic (apparently, shooting someone in the leg made fatal chest wounds) but it's...well-designed. The cases are all realistic with carefully designed motives and chain of events. You'll find the thrill of being in a crime scene looking for clues like footprints, shoe sizes, blood traces, injury marks, and other 'detective stuff'. You also get to judge whether someone is telling the truth or lying by looking into their faces and voice tone. Facial expression is carefully designed to show real-life 'lying' or 'truth' or 'holding out' expression (e.g. eyes looking left when lying). Bored of the same routine? Whenever you're driving, you'll receive dispatch calls that will give you side-missions. So yeah, the main advantage of this game is its well-designed gameplay.

The bad parts of the game is really not that much and does not affect the gameplay. Graphics looks very low-budget, it's as if they put all of the graphics money into character's facial expression realism. But in my opinion, it's still in the acceptable level. The weapon choice is also very limited, only Colt 45, Thompson, M1 Garand, and BAR. Since the game is not focused on the gun fights, this issue has miniscule effect.  And as a good guy, you don't get to do the legendary GTA reckless driving. You don't have to follow traffic rules and all but you can't run over pedestrians or ram cars that cut you off if you don't  want your case report to be ruined. Some of the cases are also pretty complicated, giving you a long list of person of interest and clues. This particular mission gave me the 'What am I doing? Who the heck is this guy? Whoa, now who are you? What's their connection to the case?' moment. But that's the fun part, right?

In conclusion, the gameplay is very unique and I don't think there are many open-world detective games out there. This advantage makes this game a 'must-play' for me and it's worth every cent. I spent over 13 hours and I'm not even a quarter finished of the whole game. The cons of the game is almost meaningless and it will not ruin the gameplay. I definitely recommend this game, it's worth it.

reviewText:
Finally a game where you play as a cop! And not some traffic warden but a Los Angeles detective Cole Phelps.
The investigation process is the second best part of the game, after the story (see below). The search for clues will make you really punctilious and bring deep insight into all cases. The interogation is even better with the best game facial animation I have ever seen making some characters an obvious liars whereas others might seem honest. What kind of police officer would you be without chasing criminals? This takes me to the third part of police work and that are the gunfights and chases on foot or in cars. These elements aren't the main plus of the game since it's not a shooter of any kind - if you want to buy the game for the action only, don't. However, though these are weaker than in Mafia II for example, they are a nice contrast to the peaceful investigation and they balance the neat investigating with some action, which is important for you not to get bored from finding clues only.
Apart from the extraordinary facial animation the graphics is about average. The city of LA is really big and contains lot of hidden secrets, such as cars, sights etc. for completionist gamers. Though the city really is wonderful, it doesn't feel as lively as it might be. Apart from the cases and street crimes, there isn't much to watch. But that isn't much of a drawback - not many games have that (maybe the Watch Dogs will).
Finally, the story. There's a lot to spoil so I'll take this just briefly. It focuses on many things and mentions lot of important topics, which make it really strong. As set in the year 1947, it connects the horrors of war and Cole Phelps' military history with the police investigations and lot of other topics, you'll encounter in the streets of LA such as drugs, racism, prostitution, rapes and lot more. I enjoyed the last Arson desk a whole damn lot because it shows nobody is plain black or white, evil or good. Some characters are antagonists, though you feel the morale in their acting, others have it the other way round. It also shows how thin line lies between good and bad, between friends and enemies.
To sum up - this game promises something quite different from others as you'll be playing at the right side of the law meaning lots of new aspects and a fantastic story. The weakest thing I can think of is that you cant skip the ending credits :)
9/10

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a beautiful tale of the grime that lurks just below the surface.

GAMEPLAY:
There are 4 main types of gameplay at work here the first is investigation, the second is interrogation, the third is car chases, and the fourth is gunfights. The first and second forms mentioned make up the meat of the game with 90% of the game consisting solely of walking around, picking things up, and talking to people. The gunplay and driving could both be improved, but they both occur so infrequently and can be skipped that it is hardly considered a real negative. The biggest issue I have with the gameplay is the Truth
recommended: Lie" function. The majority of the time you'll be going out on a whim if you doubt or lie. The best you can do is choose lie first to see where Cole takes it
hoursPlayed:
and if you didn't mean to head that direction choose doubt instead. Also a lot of the time what you need to present for lie will be a toss up for 2 items and the one you choose probably won't be it even though it could work. The fact is though I can't think of any way to solve the issues it has.

STORY:
This is what the game is about. I don't want to spoil anything about the story
voteText:
but just remember to never take a single thing you hear at face value not even the character you play. The set up is you play as Cole Phelps a war hero turned LAPD detective in the mid-late 40's. One of the best qualities of this game is the writing of all of the characters. Every single aspect of the characters was clearly taken and cared for to be formed into one of the best experiences that can be given to anyone who is willing to look one step deeper.

SOUND:
Limited repeated tracks with hit-or-miss voice recordings (some people sound like they were recorded in a cardboard box while standing in the middle of the street) leave much to be desired.

Cons:
*30 FPS locked
*Lots of random stutter
*Large wonderful but shallow overwold.

OVERALL:
If Phoenix Wright had an affair with the 40's this game would be what pops out. And I loves meself some Phoenix Wright. L.A. Noire deserves to be on the forefront of anyone's "to-play" list if you have a marginal interest in Noire or love a good  story."

reviewText:
Justice always wins.At the bottom, there is a short version as a summary for those who don't like to read.

Phelps, badge 1247.
So.. your name is Cole Phelps. After the end of World War II you return to the country as a hero and as one of the few soldiers who deal well with the trauma of the experiences on the front lines. You have always thought that everything is either black or white and guided by these ideals you are joining the ranks of police in Los Angeles. At first, being a simple novice from the proverbial traffic police
date:
you manage to get promoted to the rank of detective in a special department of the LAPD, thanks to solved case. From now on, all your days will pass on briefings, visual inspections of crime scenes, interrogations and prosecutions of suspects.

Mechanics of investigation looks like this: we arrive at the briefing and we learn what case are we supposed to solve. Then we go to the scene of the crime (most often we are dealing with murder), we are making an inspection of the place and we are looking for evidence that could be helpful in the case. When we are close to some significant object, the game tells us via a specific sound, so we know that in this place there is something important, of course, you can turn it off. Each of evidence gives us some new clues. After collecting relevant evidence (in which may include the murder weapon, bills, bank statements, wallets, pictures and others), it's time to hear witnesses on the scene. When you hear the answer to the question we asked, we can decide whether a person is telling the truth, if you doubt in what he/she says (though we have no direct evidence for this), or perhaps he/she is lying. After some time we reach the potential suspects, in which hearings can be supported by evidence found at the crime scene. A further order of investigation is generally subordinated to the scenario outlined by the authors, however, led by our hearings or visits to key locations can accelerate or delay the investigation. And don't worry, in the final phases of the investigations no shortage of gunfights and car chases, but if you want more shoot, invest in side missions and occupy a street crimes.

When it comes to graphic design here is a little bit worse, though facial expressions and general appearance of characters fully make up for that. While the city itself has two sides of the coin: nicely presented (I mean here especially for skyscrapers, parks, alleys and smaller houses), but quite often creates the impression of a slightly extinct. On the streets moves fewer people than would indicate the size of this metropolis. And I must admit that the size of the virtual Los Angeles makes quite an impression when we launch the map available on the menu. The execution of city lacks nothing, but I would feel that it is really alive!

Sound design and music is definitely one of the strengths of this production. The soundtrack is filled with 26 songs inspired by the era in which the game takes place and it is not climatically, but simply phenomenal. Subtle jazz sounds in execution of trumpets, saxophones, percussion and string instruments is a mixture, which any movie of the higher shelf wouldn't be ashamed of. A more dynamic compositions also don't stick out on a step from the rest. Equally excellent are the voices of all the characters. This game is a feast for our ears.

The icing on the cake in L.A. Noire was supposed to be perfectly devoted facial expressions of the characters created by a special session of the motion-capture engulfing the faces of real actors and I must admit that it works very decently. Although facial expressions, if you can call it that way, are very stereotypical and relatively easy to recognize whether a person is calm or hiding something.

SUMMARY (TL:DR)
In L.A. Noire players have received what they wanted most: climate, climate and climate once more. Detective sheath, an advanced facial expression betraying emotions of the characters, crime mysteries of the City of Angels, charismatic characters and music that simply melts in our ears compensate for slightly brutal simplification of the sections of arcade and a little disappointing visuals. Sincerely, this is one of my favorite titles.

reviewText: Since they felt the need to put this on the front page of Steam again, I thought I'd come point out that this is one of the worst PC ports you can play. It's capped at 30 FPS(ugh), meaning it's very choppy. It also has a lot of issues that were never fixed.It's a shame really because it's a nice looking game, but it was basically shovelwared to PC with no effort or respect for the platform. It's a lot like the Dark Souls PC port, which is also terrible. And like that game, it's highly rated. These games are TERRIBLE on PC, yet have glaring ratings. This is why you shouldn't trust Metacritic with console ports. Everyone is over rating these because the console version is good... that's nice and all... except that we're talking about the PC version here, in the PC section, and on Steam. You can also read plenty of reports about crashes or freezes(from people that have actually played it).\n\nIf you want this, get it on a console. Do not get it on PC. The PC version is absolutely terrible, and most of the reviews(even in the PC section of Metacritic) are praising it because of the console version, aka, idiots that'll probably never even try the version they are giving positive ratings to. Rockstar is another company that cares very little about the PC players, usually just shovelware porting their console games onto the platform. Btw, it also has Rockstar Studios attached to it, even on the Steam version.

reviewText:
The atmosphere in this game is great, it's a sleazy 1940s LA straight out of a Raymond Chandler novel. The immersion is sometimes broken by the odd daft action sequence but overall the story is well written and executed with great voice acting and facial expressions on the models.

The game is really all about the story. Although it is open world there is little to interact with - the huge and beutifully detailed game world is more there for the immersion.

The main downside is that it runs horribly on PC. The game engine is locked to 30fps apparently and there are often fps drops whenever there is anything fast happening on screen. When compared to other open world games with fantastic graphics like Mafia 2 and Skyrim this game runs like a one-legged asthmatic pensioner. Seems Rockstar don't make any effort to optimise their games for the PC master race anymore.

Overall I can recommend it as the techincal issues are not game breaking because 95% of the time it is exploration/puzzle/adventure type gameplay and not action/shooter type gameplay where the crappy framerate would soon give you a headache.

reviewText:
The second world war is over, The Cold war is dawning for the United States, and for Cole Phelps, a man from San Francisco, who spent the war in the Pacific theatre and fought bravely in the Battle of Okinawa, and even see and do things he wish he hadn't, returning with a Purple Heart, it means returning to the Golden State and the city of Angels, whilst he starts from the ground up on patrol, Cole slowly rises through the ranks of the Los Angeles Police department, solving groundbreaking cases and massive crime sprees as he tries to pick up the mess 1 case at at time. Cole soon realizes that the City of Angels has its share of demons, and that the Golden State has a much darker tone than advertised.

Everything from Vice to Arson, Cole Phelps assumes the position of multiple police investigation desks following promotions and the like, and solves the cases given, not every time with the correct criminal put behind bars, with 4 desks in total. (Not counting Patrol)

The cases branch from stopping the morphine street trade, ending a corrupt Housing development's scheme, and even going after the an Argentine consulate for Pedophillia and corruption. Rather than focusing on gunning down everyone, Cole must use his wit to interrogate thugs and friends alike to get to the bottom of it all.

There are even short street missions that can occur during missions or in free roam, where Cole will end up putting his combat training to use against common street thugs.

My Complaint, is that it's a crappy console port, and runs really poorly; this is to be expected somewhat, as the characters are filmed with special facial technology that is filmed at 30 frames per second, running the game at a reasonable pace breaks the audio and characters entirely, so I can see why it's so poorly optimized.

Whilst I was able to get it running by literally going for the lowest graphical settings, it's much better to buy this on a console if you have one, as for the time being, the PC version simply can't run faster than 30 frames and isn't the best optimized, and unless some major update fixes all this, the game will continue to have these problems.

Do I recommend this title? Yes, I do, ignoring the frames it's a great game and certainly one of the most interesting Rockstar titles, and games in general in a long time.

reviewText:
AAI + GTA

Thirty five hours, much longer than I expected it would be.

You'll probably spend most of the time driving from one point to the next, but if you ever feel like that's too tedious you have fast travel.

Cases were well put together as were the investigations. Shooting gangsters was nothing to write home about, but the vehicle chase segments were fun (even if civilians saw fit to throw themseleves at the front of my car half the time).  Speaking of cars, there's 95 different varieties of magnificently archaic vehicles for you to find and commandeer if that's your thing (it should be).

The game might have crashed four or five times but the autosave prevented any serious loss of time.

One of the most varied games I've seen in awhile, strong on a lot of fronts and always prime to switch up on you before it gets too stale.

Stout Scarab best car in the game.

reviewText:
Let's start out with what you will probably be looking at the most: the facial animations are amazing and will help you decide if a suspect is lying or telling the truth. The graphics still look pretty decent for an older game and L.A. Noire has a fantastic atmosphere and a great soundtrack. Altough the game doesn't really have a main story, the individual cases are really interesting and well put together. Even if L.A. Noire is by no mean a free roaming game there are some fun side activity's to do. You can search the city for unlockable cars, view points(certain locations) and there are some side missions to do. The game also has some nice shootouts and chases!

Sadly, this game also has some downsides. The city of Los Angeles can feel a bit empty at times and the cases can feel a bit repetitive after a while. After finishing about 70% of L.A. Noire (DLC included) it just felt to repetitive and my interest in the game was lost. I think this is mainly because there is no real story, just some individual cases.

All together i would still highly recommend this game. It's truly an amazing expierence and well worth the money, Even if you don't finish it completely.

reviewText:
Visit the 1940s Los Angeles and help the young LAPD detective Cole Phelps solve crimes ranging from arson to serial murder. L.A. Noire is a third person open world adventure with great graphics, amazing soundtrack and fantastic voice acting.

PROS:
- very good storyline
- amazing graphics
- huge world to explore with infinite details
- 90 car types you can drive and driving around is a lot of fun, there are some really cool car chases
- character depth and development
- great old-timey jazz soundtrack
- voice acting and facial expression detail
- overall noir atmosphere
- if you like drainpipe climbing, this game is a perfect choice

MEH:
- it's quite easy when you come to think of it: most clues are right there and you can miss some of them, you can make some wrong accusations during interrogation and still successfully solve the case
- some action sequences are rigged: you are not allowed to catch the criminal too quickly, so that you have to run/drive all the fun locations developers have prepared for you (and the locations are great, so I forgave that easily)

CONS:
- the game saves only at certain points, so there are moments where you may lose 10 minutes of gameplay if you suddenly quit
- some cutscenes are quite long

To sum up: one of the greatest games I've ever played. Masterpiece!

GAMEPLAY 9/10
GRAPHICS 10/10
AUDIO 10/10
STORY 10/10

reviewText:
Well, there has been some time since I've played a game this intriguing. L.A. Noire is more like a classical 'noir' movie rather than a computer game, and you get to play the star of the movie! The storyline centers a young, promising police officer -later detective- named Cole Phelps in 1940s Los Angeles. His tale has everything: crime, murder, trauma, love, politics, justice, conflict of interest and ethics... mostly conflict everywhere.

The atmosphere is magnificent, graphics are more than satisfying and story builds around many twists and turns, always keeping you wondering about what might come next. The investigation process is well displayed, heavily depending on observation, whether it be a mimic of a suspect, or a tone in the witness' voice. The environment is wast and it is possible to get lost if you're not following the map indicators. You carry the full option of roaming the streets of L.A. to hunt for all kinds of achievements, and even venture out to solve trivial street crimes. I once again agreed that Rockstar never abstains from investing in environment design.

Controls of the game is a bit hard to master in PC though, I think this game is better suited for PS or Xbox in that manner. Vehicles are impossibly hard to control - at least for me, but my reflexes were never that great so I'm not the one to have a final call on that -  and that would be the sole minus for me that I've observed so far. I found myself preferring my partner to drive rather than myself, and that's a bit disappointing. Oh, well: I'm not in for the perfection anyhow.

I recommend it with CAPITAL CHARACTERS; for the story, graphics and display altogether.

reviewText:
L.A Noire is a very successful hybrid between an early 90's adventure game such as Monkey Island and Broken Sword with the open world and combat/driving mechanics of GTA.
You play as Detective Cole Phelps, a WW2 veteran who is trying to work his way up the law enforcement ladder of the Patrol/Traffic/Homicide/Vice/Arson division all while trying to deal with the hostility of his co-workers and the inner corruption of the police force. If you've ever watched a Detective Noir movie like L.A Confidential then you pretty much know what to expect plot wise.

The adventure part of the gameplay will be familiar to anyone who's played adventure games in the early-mid 90's. You explore the crime scenes of your cases looking for items and clues that will help you in your investigation and then questioning the suspects of the case with the evidence that you have accumulated. The interviewing part is well done with some great voice acting and animation although the facial expressions can be a bit TOO subtle at times, you pretty much can't lose though as the story will still progress even if you get all the answers wrong.

The driving/shooting aspect is similar to any other open world game and you will be chasing and gunning down plenty of criminals during the 20-25 hour campaign. The theme and style of 1940's LA comes across really well with a brilliantly detailed city that has plenty of locations to explore, old fashioned cars to drive and a great albeit short period soundtrack.
Anyone who is a fan of Noir movies and open world games with a mix of old school adventure will have a great time playing L.A Noire.

reviewText:
LA Noire is 3rd person action game that concentrates on investigating crimes by inspecting crime scenes and interrogating witnesses. Cases are more or less unrelated, but still provide great story as a whole.
Wish they make a sequal with modern technologies and better optimization.

Good+ Story (several stories unravel at once, each on it's own pace)
+ Visuals are so-so but face animation was really good for 2011 (yes i know that it just pre-recorded stuff, like movie :( )
+ Good balanced approach to investigation (this is no easy mode, like in most of games nowadays, but it helps you a little)

Bad- GPU greedy (almost like Crysis back in 2007)
- Faces have more details than city itself.
- Rockstar Social Club (which does nothing, but slowdown start time)
- Not much of replay value
- No cloud saves
- No SteamPlay (win only)

Bottom line: worth full price if you can run it and interested in detective genre.

reviewText: GREAT game!  Seriously, this game is amazingly well done!  The story is very interesting and really fun -- a nice blend of foot chases, shoot-outs, trailing suspects in your various vintage cars, searching crime scenes, and role-playing detective work.  Also, I have to say that this game has, without a doubt, the best character animation of any video game I've ever played.  The skins of the characters are based on real actors (some of whom you'll be sure to recognize from TV and movies) and the facial espressions, mannerisms, and body language of the in-game characters is suberb!\nThe interrogation/questioning of suspects aspect of the game is, admittedly, a bit hard to learn, but once you get the hang of it it actually is one of the most interesting parts of the game.  I haven't completed the game yet; I've played about 10 hours into it.  But so far, it's awesome.\nP.S. The DLC is totally worth it too, in my opinion.

reviewText: An interesting idea and concept, let down by the terrible story pacing for the first 2/3rds of the main story. Not that you can discern there is one at that point. reviewText:
This game is amazing. In its entirety it’s intriguing and different.
I like the detail put into it. In most games simple unimportant characters don’t really have a face of their own, they just use the same few models. (E.g. the citizens in Half-Life 2) but in this, every character has their own face and therefore their own identity, and I really liked that. They were all built around their voice actors and it was really amazing to see 3 or 4 actors that I knew of, appear in a video game. That was something that really did impress me.

It’s mainly a detective type game, and there is a lot more action to it than your average detective game. You get to drive around an open world city responding to street crime, be involved in car chases, find clues for your investigation and interrogate your subjects making sure you judge them right.

I only have one problem with this game and that’s the storyline. It isn’t exactly a “game breaker” for me, I just found it a little disappointing. At first I was extremely intrigued with the plot and it felt like it was going to go somewhere great and be really good, but it just wasn’t. I found it very up and down, it leads up to one thing then completely changes the subject.
At the end of every mission you are given a score as to how well you did, and there are some points where you can’t avoid doing the wrong thing, which I thought was really stupid. There’s even one part you get told off for doing the right thing! I just thought that it was all over the place when it came to plotline.

Apart from that I think this game is great, it’s a lot of fun and it’s not something you see all that often.

reviewText:
Ok, I'll try my best not to spoil anything (wrote review after I finished the ending credits):

Waw, what a game. You're in for a rollercoaster that just gets faster and deeper the more you progress. In my opinion you should look at this game like you're participating actor in a very well done Noir series that could air on TV any day.

For a 2011 game it also still looks pretty great on full detail, the score and soundtrack is well done, suited to the era and atmosphere of the game. Cinematography feels like a movie too.

A few tips for people who are diehard about the story though:
- Take some time to see the town, you'd be surprised what you find.
- Learn from your mistakes, don't use wikia unless absolutely necessary or if you want that 5star rating on your 2nd try.
- It's an 18+ game for a reason, respect that while you play it. Some scenes really can be shocking for some people, so take it as a warning.

As conclusion (it's almost impossible to tell anything about this game without spoiling it), get it. If you fancy the era, the music, the detective genre, the noir genre, if you like puzzles, storytelling, if you like environmental accuracy or just like retro/vintage in general...

...get this game! You won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
To resume L.A. Noire quickly, it's the story of a LAPD cop named Cole Phelps and his rise & fall in the police system, all while questioning a bunch of people about various crimes. This game manages to immerse you into the past, in the late 40's as a LA police officer trying to climb the ladder.

I like alot of things about this game: The ambience, the music, the facial system, the captivating storyline, the relevance of almost everything placed in the decor, the dialogue, etc, and the list goes on. Rockstar/Team Bondi (R.I.P.) have done an amazing job on this game, making sure to create a different feel than in their previous games (such as Bully or GTA). There is no other game like this one, and that's a quality I love when it comes to good games.

The story will run you at the very minimum at least 26 hours (DLC included) and you can then retry past cases individually to try and get better. I like to play through L.A. Noire about once every 1/1,5 years (it's kinda like a movie, where it's as enjoyable as the first time once you let some time pass and come back to it).

I would recommend getting the complete edition of this game to any fan of Noire TV series or movies, and fans of well scripted detective games. DO NOT come into L.A. Noire expecting exactly the same as GTA but as a cop in the 40's because you will be very dissapointed. That being said, the game is amazing, probably the most immersive game i've played.

reviewText:
L.A Noire takes you back to 1940's Los Angeles where corruption and drugs are everyday business.
In this game you follow young ex-militairy Cole Phelps, who after winning several awards for his actions during the war signed up for the LAPD (Los Angeles Police Department)
The game allows you to solve crimes with, or sometimes without a partner. While investigating for example a murder you have the option to question a witness, by paying close attention to their facial expressions or eye movement you can find out if they're either lying or telling the truth.

Its exciting storyline and character developement is what makes this game such a masterpiece.
As you follow Cole's career from Traffic to Homicide to Vice to Arson you get the feeling of being in a 1940's crime movie. Authentic clothing and infrastructure support this feeling.

The game also allows you to free-roam, which makes it possible to drive around the city with your partner (Partner depends on what desk you chose) and respond to calls you get from the police radio.

This game could just as well be a book because of its tensive storyline and fascinating character development.
Overall I would give this game a 9/10.

reviewText:
The game is not the newest anymore and probably got plenty of reviews so I will try to be brief:

The game is set in 1947 Los Angeles and I do really enjoy the setting and the story of the main charakter as well as the story of the cases you have to solve are quite deep and interesting. ( I wont say much about it because I dont intent to spoiler).

The Missions are very well developed. You have to question suspects and pay attention for example in which order you ask questions or which evidences you provide. You have to check if you can dig up more evidence by visiting different people or points of interest, find information on places murderes happend or find information in letters, written orders or other types of papers. You often question people and either decide if they lie, tell the trueth or seem suspicious which you can tell by their facial expressions. (If they hide something they will often try to avoid looking at your or into your face and search the room with their eyes).

There are shootings happening frequently. The side missions are often based on catching someone escaping from a crime scene or even shooting down all oponents. You can use their guns. Aiming and taking cover is similiar to  GTAV.
So action is present in the game as too and balances it very well.

It is very fun even if you fail in most cases you still will move on with the story but get less points by setting up wrong evidence or accuse them of a lie while they spoke the trueth to you. There arent many games that combine those features with an open world and an interesting story.

The open world is interesting too since all the cars and environments are set in the last century. Do not expect a GTA V of course, The game is made in 2011 and the traffic AI is horrible in fact you can try to drive perfectly and the AI will simply ram you off if they want to switch the lanes.
The environment is set in LA only and you cannot really leave the city. You can visit some real life landmarks, especially the train station is very nice as you can see incomming and leaving trains but sadly its also a bit glitched.
There are no different radio stations which is a bit of a downer too. The city is very alive and you in fact are able to look into the different shops and even enter many houses and buildings.
The pedestrians however act funny too. You should avoid to run them over since you are a cop you get a message you shall protect civillians and not bring them into danger. In fact you even can lose points if you do continue bad behavior.

Another thing I personally dislike is the social club login. You always have to keep signing in but in LA Noire it simply wont save my account data and I regularyly have to retype it to be able to start the game.

I payed 5 Euroes and 99 cents but the game was completely worth it. I enjoy it a lot and since you can handle the missions very differently, there is quite some replay value as well if you wanna keep puzzling on a perfect score.

reviewText:
I'll keep it smooth and ordered:

Pro:
- REAL mimics. They used a technology where they basically filmed the actors face and put it into the game. No animations, no face capture, you see real people there. That is the main selling point - at least for me - of the game because no other game used this since then. It is very expensive, that is why.
- REAL(istic) movements. The motion capture worked really well, I rarely see this detailed animations.
- Interesting cases. They're small full stories in themselves, but most of them somehow connects to the bigger picture. You start the game as a patrol, then as you move forward you became a detective. You solve cases at each different desk, but you only start to get the picture after half of the game.
- Good main story. It is beliveable, the characters are detailed, such as their motivations. The plot twist impressed me.
- I'd say nice cars as well, but that isn't a big thing to do these days.

Contra:
- Repetitive investigating. You use the same techniques and scripted animations over and over.
- Also repetitive street crimes. Car chases, thefts and shootings. These were the three main types. Some were interesting though.
- Annoying sound bugs. Had to restart the last mission from the beginning because couldn't heard sh*t from the last cutscene.
- 30 FPS lock. And it drops below 24 even on a strong config.

This is a smart game. The developers outdone themselves with the whole facial expression and mocap feature, but they didn't put as much emphasis on important things as they should have. My 27 hours playtime felt like 40 because I got bored many times during it. Still can't dislike it, if it's on sale go and buy it.

7/10

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying: I did not expect GTA: 1940. I was told this was a puzzle game with some movie-like noir elements.

That was wrong. L.A. Noire is a boredom factory. You push some buttons, you look around, you click through some dialogue and out comes the snores. The game is simple, the action sequences are usually holding the shift button as you jump over fences and short walls and other manners of game props while chasing a bad guy, and the 'puzzle' elements involve looking for one of the many shiny clue objects in a scene (there isn't even any clutter to complicate things, the console effect means that even in supposedly hectic scenes like a recently trashed apartment there are only a few interact-able props, which the main character will almost immediately tell you “isn't relevant to the investigation”) or walking around a room until a piano note sounds, then pressing a button and rotating an object to get the ♥♥♥♥♥ detective to look at all 4 sides of a knife before deciding it could be a murder weapon.

No matter what you choose from the dialogue branches, the main character shoots off in whatever direction he fancies, so any immersion into the supposed movie atmosphere of the game is broken every time it prompts you for input because the talking heads have no flow to their discussion.

“Stick with it”, they cry, “the later cases get pretty good!”

Hogwash. It felt like a chore slogging through every single mission, at no point was I having fun. The stories aren't compelling, the gameplay isn't exciting, the puzzles aren't puzzles, and above all the voice acted dialogue sequences are an agony to sit through (not because of the voice acting, which is average at its worst). Pass, pass ten thousand times. I would rather play a real puzzle game, a visual novel, or an action game. L.A. Noire tries to do some mashup of all three and comes out a pile of turds. I think somebody accidentally released a facial emotion tech demo.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a real gem of my game library! It has everything I've ever wished for in detective games:

* Open world with 95 vehicles you can drive. There is an Auto Fanatic achievement for starting engine of all vehicles available in the game at least once. Searching for more cars in game made me look at cars parked along sidewalks irl and think if they are those which are missing ;)
* Wide variety of cases to solve under different departments of the police institute. It successfully prevents the game from being too repetitive and you get new partners to work on cases with.
* Action! You will chase criminals and suspects on foot or in a vehicle. Combat involves both fist and gun fighting depends on a situation. But you must fight appropriately back or your mission will fail and you will have to start over. Weapons can only be used during firefights. If you can't successfully finish an action mission, the game will offer you to simply skip it and move on after the 3rd try. I think that's a great deal for people who are more interested in the story than in the challenges.
* Many dialogues, questioning, truth, doubt and lie choices, great face mimic.
* Nice graphics, attention to the detail, great voice acting.
* You get to play character who's personality you learn more about through his behaviour, conversations and flashbacks of his past. You will find out he is a person who makes mistakes and who sure has skeletons in his closet.. It's pretty amazing how complex his personality is. I really like the twists we are getting there.

I must say, don't let the 30 fps cap scare you away from one of the greatest detective games. You can easily fix it and increase it to 60.

L.A. Noire is definitely worth of being finished. Towards the ending the game includes the most action scenes. Before that I used to play it when I wanted to relax after a hard day at work. Then things escalated and the story got a fast speed untill it reached the typical noire fiction ending.

I really recommend the game from the bottom of my heart. Go for it :)
