reviewText:
A new approach to the adventure genre. I‘m a fan of adventure games and i loved it. Of course the game is not perfect.
I was amazed by the graphics when it came out on PS3 and purchased it. Now i bought it with all the DLC. Rockstar know how to make DLC, this is real DLC which adds about 8-9 hours of gameplay and the quality of DLC cases is great. It‘s integrated into the story cases and you can‘t even tell whether you‘re playing DLC or not.
The facial animations still surprises me, i so want more games with similar technology. Wouldn‘t it be nice to se a walking dead game with such animations?
The overall graphics is pretty good too. But the performance is not the strongest part of this game. The game is pretty old and the framerate is not very good. Of course i used the fix which unlocks 60fps it made the game better.
Solving cases is fun, you search for the clues and talk to the witnesses and suspects and must decide if they‘re lying or not. The cases are different so it never gets boring. Story is very interesting too.
It‘s an open world game but i really don‘t understand what’s the point of it. You have nothing to do except for story and side missions. The purpose of all that open map is only to drive from point A to point B.
Anyway just grab this when you see it on sale, it‘s cheap now and is really worth it.

reviewText: Good concept but flawed execution. The problem with creating a crime solving game, which Rockstar understands, is that the average gamer won't be able to do it. The compromise to what could have been a cool mystery/policing type game is that it ends up being more of a hand-holding simulator, where most of the stuff is done for you. It's really trivial to do everything right because the game does so much by itself.
voteText: 83 of 156 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A brilliant fusion of the detective point and click genre and action games. This game is never boring as gameplay constantly changes up. One minute you will be looking for clues, the next minute you will be questioning suspects/witnesses, and five minutes later you might find yourself in a shootout, fist brawl, stakeout, foot chase, or car chase. While things might not progress in that particular order, the point is that you will find yourself doing all of these things throughout the course of the game, or even within the same case. The game starts to feel like many games combined into one, but the transition is seemless. This game is a must buy for those that want something different and wouldn't mind role-playing as a cop. The game itself is genre breaking and doesn't quite fit into any one genre, which is a good thing in an age where many games stick to stale tried-and-true formulas.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
L.A. Noire, why are you so entertaining and so disappointing at the same time?

L.A. Noire is mostly the story of Cole Phelps, a former-marine-now-policeman working in the Angels' city. As such, he will have to work his way up the food chain, starting in patrol, soon to be promoted to trafic, homicide and what not.

The game is a mix and match of several genres: it's a bit of a point n' click, but with third-person shooting and driving around, in a beautifully recreated L.A. Mostly, you'll be collecting clues on crime scenes, and interviewing suspects, while a partner lets you do all the work and comments on your action.

Those parts are great. Thanks to some fancy facial-capture technology and the help of professional actors, the characters of L.A. Noire feel alive, and real. You can see their expression on their faces, notice when they tell the truth or when they lie (in which case you gotta shove a clue you collected into their face). Coles Phelps yells, gets mad, doubts... In a very convincing way. The cast includes many well-know series actors, from Madmen, Breaking Bad or Twin Peaks.
What's more, the shooting parts (relatively frequent) aren't that bad, for an investigation game.

But L.A. Noire's greatest success is its wonderful film noire atmosphere. Secret loves, murders, illegal gamblings, corrupted politicians and cops, jazz, femmes fatales... Everything is right here, in a post-WW2 US. A country that feels invincible, but whose confidence hides nasty stories.

Great, heh?

Yeah, except that L.A. Noire also disappoints. If you don't stick to the cases you're supposed to be solving, you quickly find out its greatest weakness: Los Angeles has no soul. The city is beautiful, mind you. But nothing happens. Car drives around, people walk. There are a few scripted events. But that's about it. You can't drive around and tail someone just because he looks weird. The game has to tell you to do it. You can't get into a restaurant a get yourself a coffee and read the news. You can't discuss with people. The city feels like a beautiful, but empty playground.

If you're expecting a game that looks and plays like Gran Theft Auto, let's say you might be turned off by L.A. Noire. The game has little in common with Rockstar' behemoth. But if you like the film noire genre, and are willing to put up with sometimes clunky or repetitive gameplay, then you ought to try L.A. Noire. I personnally see the game as an interactive story (a bit like The Walking Dead), taking place in an open world where you can drive fancy old cars. Too bad the game could have been so much more.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Only a couple hours in, and I am completely amazed by this game. The facial details in this game are unparalleled (even for a 2011 game), even though sometimes the character's facial movements/expressions do not help you in interrogation. The story is also not completely erratic like others, yet keeps you on track enough just to keep you coming back for more. However, the game is not without it's flaws. Tasks such as running and gunning while goons are unloading whole mags on you feels a bit unresponsive at times, and I've had some minor graphical glitches dealing with character's heads at times. Overall, it is a really good game, and I would recommend for anybody who likes a good mystery.

reviewText: L.A Noire is a Noire/Police style open world detective game from the creators of GTA and Red Dead Redemption. Think of Dragnet meets GTA lol, yeah very strange concept but it’s done right by the gameplay mechanics and the story.  It can be very tricky at first to be able to understand the basics of catching people in an act of lying, and perps not telling you everything, but it’s fun trying to figure it out and trying to solve crimes. reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a violent crime thriller that blends breathtaking action with true detective work to deliver an unprecedented interactive experience and follows the story of Cole Phelps, an ex-military and LAPD detective trying to climb in the ranks while fighting corruption and all-time high murder rates back in the 40's Los Angeles.
L.A. Noire is a such a unique adventure game that borrows many features from mystery and action games, incorporating them seamlessly in the narrative flow, creating a truly special game.
There's a wide array of vehicles and cases to solve under different departments, suspects to chase, either on foot or while driving and suspects in custody to interrogate.
The graphics are amazing, the gameplay is pretty good, the soundtrack and voice acting are marvelous but what really makes this game a masterpiece is the astonishing and engaging story and the character development.
I highly recommend L.A. Noire.

reviewText:
If you're looking for an action based game, this isn't it.
That said, if you're a fan of plot-driven, detective-work based adventure games of yore, THIS IS YOUR FIX.
The game has a massive fanbase in Japan for essentially being a visual novel with a sandbox framework, and it shows in both writing and execution.
The only real downside I can think of is the uncanny valley potential (very large here), the fact that the sandbox is underutilized unless you go on many of the sidequests for collectables, and as a whole the plot escalation being a basic snowball in pace.
In any case, a must buy for the complete version, and a major wait for a sale" if you are focused on action moreso than anything else."
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wow. Okay, wait, let's get the bad out of the way first.

1) It's optimized poorly. The game seemingly started fine, or perhaps I was too enamored with the city to notice, but DX9 or DX11, highest settings or lowest, nothing mattered. The camera would stutter, the engine would slow, and otherwise damage the otherwise breathtaking aesthetics of L.A. Noire.

2) The driver and pedestrian A.I. is atrocious. For a game that forces you to spend the majority of your time driving, expect to laugh at the ridiculous decisions made by the NPCs in this game. Then, when chasing down suspects or trying to avoid... well, I won't spoil anything, but let's just say at certain points, you will yell at the television for these dummies to get out of the way.

3) The action sequences aren't as interesting as the investigation ones. Basic action, such as the street crimes, or even a moderate shootout, aren't too bad but the above complaints tend to ruin any tension Team Bondi attempted to create.

I think that's about it. So what did I like?

1) The city. Sorry, Sleeping Dogs, you've been knocked off the top spot (previously owned by Saints Row 2) for best video game city. It's no wonder Team Bondi went bankrupt after this game. The amount of time and resources it must have taken to recreate Los Angeles is staggering.

2) The characters. Thanks to stellar voice acting and the well-publicized facial animation engine, it's easy to forget you're playing a game and not watching a movie. Tip: Play L.A. Noire in black and white and the effect is even more staggering.

3) The story. I'm a sucker for noir in general, and this is a pretty good tribute to the genre. That pretty much every single element is tied to the main story, no matter how minor it seems, is a nice touch.

4) The investigation. Whether you're screaming at a widower -- er, I mean 'doubting' a widower -- or trying to figure out how a torn letter fits with the case, I enjoyed poking around the city's seedy underbelly and solving the (many!) mysteries.

Note that I keep writing the city" instead of "the game." Yes
date: it's that realistic.\n\nI loved L.A. Noire
recommended: and if you like mysteries and history at all
hoursPlayed: please don't hesitate picking up this game. Just be warned that even at 30 FPS
voteText: a computer that laughs at the recommended specs of the latest games will (probably) not run this smoothly. Fortunately
helpfulPercent: you'll probably be too engrossed to care. I know I was."

reviewText:
If you are playing this game, play it as a glorified movie, not like a videogame.

In terms of gameplay and player agency, the things you can really do are limited. Once you get the hang of it, the lie detection system gets pretty easy too, and even if it's not, there's always the ability to reload previous saves for that perfect score.

However, it still has a really good storyline and setting. Driving around the streets of an old LA make you live in a world we would usually see in black and white, and despite what I've said before, the way you can go around a case is what can make you go missing clues or being able to score a full score on the first try.

Overall, check it out if it's on a steam sale, only if you want to see the story.

reviewText: The style of the game is perfect and the re-creation of 1940s LA is superbly done. It has revolutionised interactions with NPCs and emotional/character interactions in games. The driving is difficult to get used to, but it is worth it, if only to hear the music on the radio and the talk between your character and their partner. You do get fined for damage to property, injuries, and car damage, which I realised too late, and ended up with a very hefty fine. My advice would be to keep the speed down and stick to the middle of the road, because pedestrians have a habit of jumping in front of the car.

reviewText: Investigating thefts, robberies, disappearances and murders, all the while driving around in a huge city to get from site to site to gather clues and testimonies and, if you feel like it, respond to the occasional emergency dispatch calls (ranging from domestic disturbance to bank heist), that's what L.A. Noire is all about. Don't get fooled by the resemblance to GTA games. Yes there is a lot of driving around and some scenarios/street crimes involve shooting or fighting bad guys the same way but you'll spend more time confronting people with questioning than with your gun. Graphics are really nice and the animation...My jaw dropped the first time I saw a cutscene. The facial animation, especially, is so well done it makes you almost forget you're watching a game. This, combined with the top notch voice acting, brings the characters to life in a manner so believable you'll see actors, not computer generated dummies.  Music is also great and really suits the 40's era very well and helps to create the overall atmosphere. This one's worth buying. Still not sure? Wait until it's on sale then and get the complete edition with added scenarios.

reviewText:
If you've played a game by Rockstar before, then you probably have a good idea of what to expect from L.A. Noire. It's a lot like GTA or Red Dead Redemption — third-person gunfights, car chases and hot pursuits on foot, well-developed characters, and a compelling storyline. It's a formula that may seem almost like a crutch with how often Rockstar employs it in their titles, but it's hard to complain when it's done well.

If you're the type of person to play GTA for the plot, then L.A. Noire will keep your attention with relative ease. It does away with a lot of the nuisances that drag GTA down (there weren't even mobile phones for your cousin to call you on back in the 40's), but it also makes for — perhaps — a less substantial game, as there's not a whole lot to do besides follow the main storyline.

You play as Cole Phelps, climbing the ranks of the L.A. Police Department, slowly uncovering a massive conspiracy that reaches all the way up to the highest officials in Los Angeles. By the end of the game, you'll have managed to collect evidence from nearly every other previous case, all pointing towards systematic corruption and foul-play.

Knowing that he can bring the system crashing down is the ultimate goal that keeps Cole searching for the truth, but L.A. Noire manages to undo all player expectations with the game's finale. With an ending that nobody could possibly expect, L.A. Noire proves to be both the most shocking and most frustrating game I've played in a long time.

As confused and angry as the ending will leave you feeling, I still recommend playing the game from beginning to almost-end and then maybe just making up the last mission in your head. L.A. Noire definitely wins the prize for having the biggest f•••-you ending that a game could possibly conceive, but it's still worth the time to try it out.

reviewText: Investigating thefts, robberies, disappearances and murders, all the while driving around in a huge city to get from site to site to gather clues and testimonies and, if you feel like it, respond to the occasional emergency dispatch calls (ranging from domestic disturbance to bank heist), that's what L.A. Noire is all about. Don't get fooled by the resemblance to GTA games. Yes there is a lot of driving around and some scenarios/street crimes involve shooting or fighting bad guys the same way but you'll spend more time confronting people with questioning than with your gun. Graphics are really nice and the animation...My jaw dropped the first time I saw a cutscene. The facial animation, especially, is so well done it makes you almost forget you're watching a game. This, combined with the top notch voice acting, brings the characters to life in a manner so believable you'll see actors, not computer generated dummies.  Music is also great and really suits the 40's era very well and helps to create the overall atmosphere. This one's worth buying. Still not sure? Wait until it's on sale then and get the complete edition with added scenarios.

reviewText:
If you've played a game by Rockstar before, then you probably have a good idea of what to expect from L.A. Noire. It's a lot like GTA or Red Dead Redemption — third-person gunfights, car chases and hot pursuits on foot, well-developed characters, and a compelling storyline. It's a formula that may seem almost like a crutch with how often Rockstar employs it in their titles, but it's hard to complain when it's done well.

If you're the type of person to play GTA for the plot, then L.A. Noire will keep your attention with relative ease. It does away with a lot of the nuisances that drag GTA down (there weren't even mobile phones for your cousin to call you on back in the 40's), but it also makes for — perhaps — a less substantial game, as there's not a whole lot to do besides follow the main storyline.

You play as Cole Phelps, climbing the ranks of the L.A. Police Department, slowly uncovering a massive conspiracy that reaches all the way up to the highest officials in Los Angeles. By the end of the game, you'll have managed to collect evidence from nearly every other previous case, all pointing towards systematic corruption and foul-play.

Knowing that he can bring the system crashing down is the ultimate goal that keeps Cole searching for the truth, but L.A. Noire manages to undo all player expectations with the game's finale. With an ending that nobody could possibly expect, L.A. Noire proves to be both the most shocking and most frustrating game I've played in a long time.

As confused and angry as the ending will leave you feeling, I still recommend playing the game from beginning to almost-end and then maybe just making up the last mission in your head. L.A. Noire definitely wins the prize for having the biggest f•••-you ending that a game could possibly conceive, but it's still worth the time to try it out.

reviewText: L.A. Noire is not just a detective game, it's truly so much more in my opinion. This game is based around the late fourties when LA is at its Golden Age of the movie industry and the evy of the world. Your protaginist, Cole Phelps, is a WWII veteran now serving for the LAPD. Every section of the game, you get a new partener who specializes in that type of section of cases to be solved. The game's map is just massive, of authentic late fourties LA streets which bring great details according to the time period. Every case is based mainly how much of the clues you've found during the case, as well the damage of you've caused to the city, but mainly the interrogation questions you had to ask and confirming their 3 types. If you like these type of games, I highly recommend L.A. Noire to you.

Some FACTS about LA Noire:
- The game is 4 years old and the facial animations are STILL un-freaking-believable.

reviewText: A WW2 game that doesn't involve WW2, you play the role of Cole Phelps. A cop who, by sheer luck, stumbles upon a gruesome murder, the first two of which have racism as the motive. Eventually becoming a detective, it becomes increasingly clear that the system is completely corrupt and it's up to your scientologist friend and fake german wife to save the world from psychology while you sort vice squad cases off on the side with a shotgun and cigar. Every cop you encounter is intentionally incompitent, and you eventually get to shoot them all when your space marine firebat friend takes to the caves to fight Charlie. Origami plays a major role in the game, making it the only game to involve folding paper into little swans important.\nBecause it's California, drugs, ♥♥♥♥ on the railroad and arson by proxy cases usually lead to pedophillia and rifle stockpiles.\nOverall, a solid and unforgettable game, mostly because the villian doesn't do anything evil and never kills anyone.

reviewText:
Short version: 77%L. A. Noire, just like Rockstar’s later titles, is a controversial game. On one hand, it was advertised as some realistic detective simulator and crime drama, which is a blatant lie. On the other hand, it provides a clichéd, yet well-crafted story, some decent acting and quite a few enjoyable individual cases. Just don’t go besides the main plot: none of the side content is worth it in any way.

Long version:Although L. A. noire was initially marketed as a detective simulator, don’t fall for that: it’s about as realistic as any Hollywood blockbuster. All of the clues are in the open, almost all of the cases involve shooting and killing somebody (the story mode’s bodycount is higher than GTAIII’s), and your average everyday cop will be involved in cases that feature a Jack the Ripper style serial murder, city-wide political conspiracies, international espionage (where you’ll have to massacre a US Military compound all by yourself) and drug trafficking that would put the Columbian Cartel to shame.
Add in some very sluggish controls, the most boring and frustrating collection minigame and side missions that are literally all the same, and you may think that anyone who gave positive reviews about the title were paid large sums of money.

So why the thumbs up? Because of the story. It’s quite decently acted– the biggest weak point is Aaron Staton’s performance as the protagonist, who just looks and sounds perpetually annoyed– and even though the plot is as clichéd as you can imagine, it uses these clichés to their best. Sure, this will eliminate most of the surprise at the plot twists, but they aren’t even set up as something to be surprised of.
Plus some of the individual cases– especially for the Traffic and Arson desks– are pretty damn interesting. They are well-written crime stories, worthy to be an episode of a classic police drama. Sure, the overall plot pales in comparison, but some of the cases are so good you may want to play them again, separate from the main story.

So, in conclusion, L. A. Noire is the kind of title which you should play from start to the end once, and never again. Luckily, the main story is more than 12 hours long even if you use a guide to get past the clue-collecting phases, so you get decent amount of entertainment for your money.

reviewText:
I was pretty skeptical about this game, then it went on sale and that caught my attention. I did some research on reviews for the game and one of my most trusted sources (GameSpot) gave the game a 9 - Superb and I decided to purchase it and try it.
The game has performed pretty smooth so far and the graphics are good, but the atmosphere and visual depiction of Los Angeles is fantastic! The story line and voice acting is very good and quite absorbing. I've never been a big fan of crime detective adventure mysteries but this game has changed all that...I'm hooked, at least for L.A. Noire. The keyboard (you can customize) and mouse controls take a bit of practice but then it flows quite well.
The downside (which is very insignificant) is the auto saves, I'm not a fan of that but in a game like this that is probably the only option.
I highly recommend this game, just be sure you have a computer that can handle it...I too give it a 9 out of 10!

Patrick

reviewText:
7/10

The game is an adventure game with Rockstar trappings.

You investigate crimes, follow leads, question witnesses, interrogate suspects, and occasionally subdue criminals with force.  The game has a wondeful ambiance, a great score, and very strong characters.

Why not a better score than 7/10?  Three things cost it those three points for me:

1) The GTA"-like elements feel out of place/unnecessary.  The game is 80% criminal investigation
date: 20% action (car-chases/shoot-outs/fist-fights).  The action bits feel "tacked-on" and are not fleshed out very well in comparison to the rest of the game.  Driving between locations feels largely pointless with very little to do between points-of-interest.\n\n2) The interrogation/questioning aspect can come off as a little strange at times. You might know that a suspect is lying
recommended: but it isn't always clear if you've got the correct piece of evidence to directly accuse them of lying. When you make a bad choice
voteText: but it doesn't change the outcome of the case for the most part. The story moves forward even if you bungle all the questioning/interrogating/evidence gathering parts.\n\n3) The ending sucks. It's abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends. It feels like they ran out of time. I know that's my opinion
helpfulPercent: but I'm sure many other people feel the same."

reviewText: I'm not entirely sure what kind of game L.A. Noire actually is when you get down to the brass tacks. Is it a sandbox game? Is it an interactive novel? Is it an old-school 3D shoot-em-up? The long story cut short is that it doesn't really matter 'cause it's beautiful, has a nice retro-40s soundtrack, and is fun as all get-out! Not to mention it has a pretty brilliant story arc.

reviewText:
There is a very interesting idea in this game. It has to do with the movie industry, political corruption, war, corrupt cops, psychiatry, drugs, land speculation, cars, guns and the American dream…

SPOILERS AHEAD: The protagonist is a “hero” that makes so grave mistakes that he does not deserve to be called that. In the end, that’s exactly why the man calling him a hero is a big liar.

Jack Kelso, the man you learn to despise, ends up being the man with more character. This is a unpredictable twist, which almost saves the story. It still has some visible flaws. Still, I found it worth to play due to its interesting (but somehow flawed) investigation mechanic.

reviewText:
All in all a very atmospheric game, which allows one to submerge himself into post-war LA.

Minuses are:
- very weak in certain plot areas, which leave one wandering about the imbecility of the police portrayed, as well as the impossible prowess of the culprit in planting evidence at just the right moment (Homicide squad cases);

- there is no way to disarm an armed opponent, even if you shoot his weapon hand (which is perfectly possible due to the good aiming system), you can only shoot to kill. not a very police-like attitude.

- most cases follow a similar structure, which is theoretically hidden by their actual storyline, but can still feel like repeating routine procedures. Could count as a bonus on portraying police-work correctly though.

Despite this, in my opinion, a very worthwhile game, solid 8/10 from me.

reviewText: Why is this listed as a strategy game? It's a mystery adventure with open world elements and a bit of gunplay. If you're into crime thrillers and things of that nature then chances are you'll like the narrative as much as I do. It's really the best part of the game other than the mo-cap animations. The biggest flaw in the game is the logic you will have to follow in order to perfectly complete each case. Some trains of thought are simple to understand, some will leave you lost. Related to that is the system where you have to interview people of interest and determine if they're honest, lying or just leaving out some details. If you're unfamiliar with body habits in regards to lying (rockstar has the insight to base it on real science lol), it might be hard to get the right answer. But it's a good game and you'll get maybe 20-30 hours out of a playthrough depending if you get the complete edition. That comes with a handful of DLC cases, and most of them are pretty interesting and offer a way to flesh out certain characters more.

reviewText: A great game with a pleasant atmospheric experience based in 1940s Los Angeles as Detective Cole Phelps. The graphcs are good in terms of setting a balance of immersion by creating a very realistic vibe. The street crime cases add a bit of flavor to the overall gameplay to a game that may seem too linear to some by providing a bit of uncertainty for when the next case will come. The main cases are very interesting and carry a lot of suspense and intrigue. The downside of many of these cases is that they may become too easy for some and may not prove to be a good challenge. However, it is important to note that only the chase scenes can be a bit too easy, but actually finding the clues and persons of interests in the right order can prove to be a challenge. The controls are the typical WASD and a realistic point and shoot dynamic without any visible crosshairs. Overall, I found it a very pleasing game to play and there is a certain uniqueness that creates an enticing desire to continue to the next case.

reviewText:
This is a good game which will be overlooked as forgettable by once mountain-dew-addled-teens who are now adults as choose your own adventure GTA. This game has more in common with world exploration games and the old arcade classic Dragonslair than it ever did with the zany violent world of Grand Theft Auto.

The developers have presented an entire world full of beautiful set pieces, interesting and engaging characters and violence that is presented as a story device rather than reward for getting through the narrative elements. Sure, the game plays pretty much the same on replay but with hundreds of variations depending on who you kill, where you go first and what questions you ask.

The game has been cheap often for a long time now and if you haven't had the pleasure of digging into a game that will make you feel something different, you should get this.

reviewText: LA Noire feels like a film – LA Confidential, in fact, along with any similarly hard-boiled example of film noir adapted from stories by the likes of Chandler and Hammett. Set in a convincing depiction of Los Angeles in 1947 , it casts you as Cole Phelps, returning war hero turned cop.\n\nL.A. Noire blends the breathtaking action of chases and shootouts with true detective work including interrogations and clue-finding.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In typical Rockstar/GTA-style, L.A. Noire puts you into the role of Detective Cole Phelps, a war hero who is now is fighting crimes at the police of Los Angeles in the early 1940s.

During the game you join 5 different police divisions, each with their own field of activity: Patrol, Traffic, Homicide, Vice, Arson. Each division features 4 to 6 varying cases, which are - some more, some less - tied together. There is also a major backstory that runs like a thread through all divisions and cases.

Detective work involves a lot of search for clues and interrogation which, thanks to the Motionscan technology, provides never before seen facial animations in the game to make it possible to tell apart whether or not your suspect is lying.

A complete playthrough will take you, at the very least, 20 hours, however, if you inspect the crime scenes overly carefully and make use of all dialogue options, you can easily get 25, 30 or more hours of gameplay out of it, so it's well worth its money!

reviewText: Wow, what a game... first, let me say that I've always been interested in WWII and the post-war world in the United States.  This game combines all my interests into one package.  It is fascinating to just drive around and look at things (clothes, cars, shops, etc...) and see how they were in 1947.  The gameplay is also well done too, you basically wander around in L.A. and try to solve crimes by looking for clues and talking to people.  The lip-synching is fantastic, L.A. Noire could almost pass for an animated movie.  When questioning witnesses, you have to really look at their faces to see if they are lying or telling partial truths, it takes some practice but you'll get good at it with just a little time.  Think of this game as a time machine back to the late 1940's, it lets you experience the time period in a way that you could never do by just reading books or watching movies.  I was a little worried about the performance issues I'd read about but the game runs absolutely fine on my old dual core PC (with a few small additions in the launch options).  I highly recommend this game to anyone who is on the fence about it... get it now and start playing, you won't regret it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To me this is the best game of all time. It mixes so many genres, the gameplay never fails to keep you entertained. The story keeps your interest to the max, thanks to the narration that ties you to the main character and his mates. All the protagonists are charismatic and their expressions are just fascinating (the realism of it is just mindblowing).

The atmostphere of the 40s is there, every single little detail is there. Even though the story is linear, you never feel that you have to follow X point to Y.
The investigation system with the puzzles you have to discover is just a MASTERPIECE - everything you do have an impact on the final result of your investigation. And most of all... You have to recall every single things you have seen/done/heard to solve your investigations. That means you really have to be involved into the game!

This game combines : TPS/Shooter - Advanced investigation with examination of the different suspects - Point & Click" (you have to find the clues on the murder scene) - Open world exploration - Arcade driving...

I totally loved this game and I am more than sad that the studio closed after this masterpiece... My advice is... :
Buy it if you want to try something that has never been done ever in gaming!"

reviewText: L.A. Noire is an engrossing tale derived the famous City of Angels that has you playing the role of an L.A.P.D. detective.  It features a vast open-world environment set in 1947 just after the Second World War. The characters, level of detail and the mature setting draws you into the era and presents the player with a unique blend of third-person action and point-and-click adventure. You will be thrown into car chases, foot pursuits, shootouts, interviews and setup to investigate crime scenes where you must establish motive and means. L.A.  Noire is simply a must for gamers!

Fantastic game. Facial expressions and acting are the best I've seen in a game, and the detective gameplay is simply genius making you try to figure out if someone is lying by watching their faces. reviewText: Police procedural. It's a word you hear a lot when descriibing TV cop dramas. Despite how exciting those shows can be, the word itself sounds like something incredibly boring. Probably in real life it most often is. Great music and montages can do a lot to make a detective's life look enviable. The problem with LA Noire is that there are no montages. There's this huge world to explore, yet there's no reason or pull to. Each chapter, or 'case' is so short and contained that it never feels like the right time to go exploring. Why then make the game appear so much like a sandbox? Being 'on mission' all the time, having such a focus on realism, being rated constantly: it all amounts to nurturing a fear of experimenting and going off track. Yet these are the things which evoke fun times. I enjoyed the experience of LA Noire for the unique one that it was, but I probably won't be heading back.

reviewText:
A truly unique game, executed well. Instead of playing as a dangerous criminal, you play as the good guy who is trying to solve crimes.
This game takes place in 1940s LA. Rockstar managed to recreate the world well and it provides a unique atmosphere to the game. There's not going to be too many instances where you go around killing people with your gun, because this is supposed to be an investigation game, rather than a open world city sandbox game. The plot can be unpredictable, and keeps the player interested to continue the game. Graphics are quite nice, and the DLCs are also worth trying.
However, the PC version is by flawed, too. The game seems to be poorly optimized for PC, as it has a 30fps lock and many people have a hard time running this game.
Get it, if you can find a way around the 30fps lock and can fix the game with some mods.
9/10

reviewText:
This was only the second game on the Xbox 360 that I got 100% of the achievements for (Oblivion being the 1st).  This is still one of my favorite games.  I've been keeping an eye on the PC version for a while and finally scored a great sale during Christmas 2013.  It was awesome picking this back up after years of having it beaten on the Xbox.  The PC version looks much better and it works flawlessly with the Microsoft controller for WIndows.

LA Noire uses the RockStar Social Club.  It is not required, but it is handy to use the club's stats pages to check your game progress if you are shooting for 100% completion.  I found it easier to create a R* account via their website before going into game.  The Social Club still has my 360 stats as well as my new PC stats.

It is a shame that the developer studio was closed down years ago.  Hopefully R* will find another developer to make a sequel to this awesoms game.

reviewText:
Story - I should start off this review by saying I am totally biased in favor of this game and it is my favorite game in my library at the time of writing.  I love the setting of the 1940's and especially the noir and detective aspects.  This game is the closest you will get to playing L.A. Confidential: The Video Game.  I found the story and even the individual cases to be very engrossing and they feel like actual crimes that could have been committed.  I love a video game with a great story above all else and this one totally delivers on that.  All of the characters feel very real and have more depth than in other Rockstar games.  Cole Phelps, the protagonist, at first seems like a squeaky clean detective, but as the story goes on, that changes and you become very engrossed in him as a character.  When you add a deep and perplexing murder myster to that, I was hooked.  There are even real historical characters (gangsters like Bugsy Siegel) in the game and scientology makes an appearance (in an interesting way) too.

Gameplay - You assume the role of Detective Cole Phelps and investigate crimes, interrogate suspects, tail suspects, and sometimes get in shoot outs and fist fights.  I really like the way L.A. Noire handles investigations.  You have to find clues at the crime scenes by picking up and examining objects.  When you find suspects, you can interview them and respond in three ways (truth, doubt, or lying) depending on what they say.  This is probably the most challenging part of the game because unless you're very good, it can be hard to know whether to doubt or call the suspect a liar.  You can and will arrest the wrong person if you get too many questions wrong or don't find all the evidence.  Fortunately, there are plenty of guides out there to help you if you are worried about getting it wrong.  In total, the game has somewhere between 20-30 cases and it took me around 30 hours to get through them all.  I never got tired of playing L.A. Noire and would have played many more cases if I could.

A lot of the other game play is really similar to Grand Theft Auto.  Driving is arcadey in a good way and shooting is cover based and pretty fun too.  While you spend more time investigating in missions than doing shooting and car chases, the game also offers street crimes which are often foot or car chases with a shoot out or a fist fight thrown in.  These aren't necessary to beat the game but they are fun and were a nice addition.

Presentation (Graphics and Sound) - The graphics in L.A. Noire are both dated and incredibly impressive at the same time.  I'm pretty sure this game uses a version of the Grand Theft Auto 4 engine and while the graphics are solid, they do look like a PS3 game and if you have a good gaming pc, you can certainly find games that look better.  What makes this game great though is the acting and animation of the characters.  L.A. Noire uses a newer animation system that captured the way the voice actors looked and acted when delivering the lines.  This makes it possible to see when someone is lying and it also makes the characters look really distinct and believable.  I hope we'll see more games use this technology in the future.  In addition, the makers of this game put an incredible amount of detail into replicating the Los Angeles of the 1940's.  The city looks and feels real.  There is so much detail and nothing feels recycled when you drive around.

The sound is excellent from the voice acting to the authentic music on your car radio when you drive around.  I love the theme song for this game and think it sets the mood for the game better than almost any other I've seen.

Overall - As I said at the beginning, I truly love this game.  From the story to the realism to the satisfying game play, I think L.A. Noire has it all.  If you don't care about these things, especially a great story then it is very possible you will like this game a lot less than I do or lose interest in it before beating it.  I've certainly heard people say that they felt this way and I think this is just one of those games that some people will really love and others will just find to be pretty good.  However, if my review sounds appealing to you, this game is one of Rockstar's best and that is really saying something.

As far as achievements go, this game is very easy to get a high percentage on by playing through the game once and trying to grab achievements as you go.  You will want to find a good guide for getting five stars on every case and for making sure to use all the weapons in the game or you will have to repeat parts of the game.  The one that kept me from trying to get them all is an achievement that makes you drive every car in the game.  There isn't an easy to find all of these cars and you almost need some luck to get them all.  That one is a bit of a bummer but I would still say that compared to other games, L.A. Noire has more reasonable achievements, especially if you can live with getting 90% or so of them.

9.5 (out of 10)

reviewText:
All in all a very atmospheric game, which allows one to submerge himself into post-war LA.

Minuses are:
- very weak in certain plot areas, which leave one wandering about the imbecility of the police portrayed, as well as the impossible prowess of the culprit in planting evidence at just the right moment (Homicide squad cases);

- there is no way to disarm an armed opponent, even if you shoot his weapon hand (which is perfectly possible due to the good aiming system), you can only shoot to kill. not a very police-like attitude.

- most cases follow a similar structure, which is theoretically hidden by their actual storyline, but can still feel like repeating routine procedures. Could count as a bonus on portraying police-work correctly though.

Despite this, in my opinion, a very worthwhile game, solid 8/10 from me.

reviewText:
One of my favourite games.  Extremely well researched 1940s setting.  Occasionally things are phrased in very non-American ways owing to the game's Australian origin but besides that the setting is flawless.  Monroe's old-time Irish-American accent is lovely.  You won't hear that stuff from yanks these days (not to mention John Noble's fecking Australian; brilliant).
The game itself is mostly flawless detective work, with some nice car chases and shootouts but most of it's nigh-perfect detective work.
One of my favourite things about the game is the fact that it's obvious every single section was tweaked after applying the initial foundational mechanics.  You can tell they cared.
And the story is fantastic.

reviewText:
Review of L.A Noire - Complete Edition
Positive:
+Great storyline, easy to follow and understand!
+Graphics aren't too bad for game released 2011
+Several missions, even more with the ''DLC''
+The DLC whitch gives you several new outfits and unlocks many cases for you to solve out, is practically free for you because the main game costs witouth sales 29,99€ meanwhile the DLC whitch includes original game, is 29,99€ = Profit for you!
+Achievements, and several puzzles for you to solve if you want to take break of the main-story
+Huge map of Los Angeles, dating back to the mid and late 40's, they did well with getting the atmosphere there!

Negative:
-Team Bondi does not accurenly show any kinda of interest to this game, there have not been a single update to this game after I bought it, whitch was in Summer Sale 2014, a fairly long time ago!
-Yes there is many cars, but I'd like if you could ride the trams and busses in the game too tho' this is not a big deal at all
-The worst thing with this game is it's support for PC version is just... Bad, this was made for the consoler first, and then the team got lazy on importing it to PC version so they just took the exact copy of the X360 and PS3 versions and put it in the PC version = 30FPS lock, and it looks f*cking bad! It can be removed with a program but that does not completely fix it, instead makes it worse in some cases i.ex when driving a vehicle, the physics becomes very bad and you can not steer the vehicle almost at all, but I recommend you to turn it off while driving and just trying to survive that 30FPS maddnes, it's just a game afterall I guess...

Altho' some of it's negative feedback I gave this game, I can easilly give this game a 8.5/10 rating!

reviewText:
COMPLETED 100%


Game has a great flair of originality in it with gameplay elements you don't see in any other game out there. The open world is rendered beautifully in 1940s L.A. with incredibly detailed landmarks and plenty of interiors you can just walk straight into and explore even with no incentive given to do so.

What it does good though, it fails a largely in repetitiveness and a rather disconnected story that mostly just consists of a bunch of cases that always ends up with you arresting the culprit, guilty or not, it doesnt even matter. The same game elements like investigations and interrogations that looked interesting at first eventually starts getting stale and might become quite a chore to do, with so little in the way of variation.
Trying to ace interviews and interrogation scenes are not the least easy and sometimes the correct answers (Lie, Doubt, Truth) doesn't make sense. I started this game mostly looking forward to a good detective noir story but what turned out instead is quite a disappointment. The central plot only gets underway in the final desk of the game making everything you did before nothing more than random crime cases. Story overall is nothing impressive and even seemed quite rushed. Mediocre at best.
Look past the flaws however, and the game still holds up with brilliant dialogue and voice acting and exceling in innovation in its own rights.

reviewText: I'd forgotten how much of an immersive and distinctive storytelling experience L.A. Noire is in the four years since I completed it on the Xbox 360. It's essentially a hardboiled detective novel brought to life in a highly cinematic gaming experience. I just picked up the complete edition on sale for dirt cheap, and before I knew it, I was spellbound and had spent the entire evening playing it for several hours straight in a single sitting. As the minutes turned into hours, I found myself once again drawn into the game's shadowy world of vice, corruption, and murder that brilliantly captures the atmosphere of 1950s Los Angeles in a medium it had never been explored. The narrative revolves around one main character and a few minor ones and slowly (some would say tediously; this is not a typical open world sandbox game, so don't approach it like one...it requires patience and an open mind) progresses through a series of cases in which you repeat many of the same gameplay elements (inspect crime scenes for clues, go to new locations they lead you to, track down and interrogate suspects, and rinse & repeat in various orders with some chase & gunfight sequences thrown in for pacing as well as optional dispatch missions you can take on in the middle of a case), but the writing, variety of rich settings, and overall presentation are top notch and keep the formula fresh and the mysteries (both in individual missions and the overarching story) tantalizing regardless of linearity. The graphics have aged a bit (even running on maximum settings, pop-in is more evident, draw distance is shorter, and environmental textures that comprise foliage & buildings are much less detailed than the current standards), but none of that detracts from the experience or the dense, vibrant world and performances that made this game so great back in 2011. In fact, the motion capture technology it employed was far ahead of its time, allowing it to showcase nuanced facial expressions that weren't matched by other videogames until only around a year ago. This PC port is outstanding, running at a high, stable frame rate and improving on an already visually compelling console game.\n\nIf you haven't played this yet, I highly recommend it, especially since you can now get the complete package for around $5 which includes the original four standalone DLC missions and two previously console-exclusive missions that are inserted into the campaign, making this akin to a director's cut. A modern classic and smart, savvy game with dark themes for mature audiences.

reviewText:
By the time I am writing this review, I have not yet finished the game, but I am 10 hours in and would like to share my opinion and impressions, which hopefully will help you to decide whether you should get this game.

First of all, I'll start with the positive things:
- The vibe and atmosphere/Setting: They did an AWESOME job at setting up the right setting and getting into the spirit of LA in 1947, at least IMO. I do like this period a lot, and the look of the game (if you like, you can play this in b/w as well), the music/radio broadcasts (unfortunately, no way to switch radio stations manually, apparently. No custom music either, but then again, listening to modern music in the car would kinda ruin the immersion), the cars, fashion, lingo etc... just GREAT.
Also, since this is based on old thrillers and stories by guys like Raymond Chandler, they went for that vibe, and did it VERY well... this does feel a lot like a that noire crime fiction Chandler was famous for.

- The general idea is very cool and, IMO, refreshing - interrogating people and, based on the clues you found and their facial expressions (done with actors and motion capture) figuring out whether they're lying or not... great job there! The IGN review says that sometimes, it is too easy to tell when someone is telling a lie or getting nervous - but doesn't that add even more realism? After all, not everyone is a good liar irl!

- The gameplay. The cars DO feel a bit... odd, chases can get a tiny bit frustrating, the shooting mechanics are far from perfect, but between examining crime scenes, searching for clues, interrogating witnesses and suspects, using your notebook to find clues, car chases, shootouts and some interludes to deepen the story, there is some variety.

- The characters. I really like the main protagonist, and some of his fellow policemen. Sure, there is quite a bit of clichè to be found here, but that again fits well, as this is a tribute to the noire-genre, which never was deep literature anyway.

Now for the less than positive or even negative parts:

- On rails. To a certain degree, the game takes away your freedom. An example: In one case, I apparently missed a clue at one of the places I visited. I was doing interrogations at the police station, and was not able to go back to those places and pick up the thing I missed, which would have made solving the case easier and unlocked some additional questions/accusations.

- Evidence. Basically, if you think a person is not telling the truth, you wanna choose doubt". If you pick "lie"
date: you have to prove the person is a liar with a piece of evidence/clue from your notebook. And sometimes that doesn't work right. Not a bug
recommended: it's the writing. The abbreviated details of the clue or piece of evidence might make you think that it is clear evidence the guy is a liar
voteText: the game says it's wrong or not enough.\n\n- Some frame rate issues. This game is by no means recent. I don't have a killer gaming pc (i7

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: IF YOU WISH TO PLAY ON 60FPS, USE WIDESCREENFIXER SINCE THIS GAME IS LOCKED IN 30FPS. FOR FOV, USE FLAWLESS WIDESCREEN AND PRESS EITHER + OR - TO CHANGE THE VIEW. THE PORT FOR THIS GAME ISN'T REALLY THAT GOOD BUT THE GAME ITSELF IS.

LA Noire is an open world detective game set in the 1940s after WWII. You play as a Cole Phelps, a marine turned police officer then detective. You solve cases from traffic to homicide to vice and then arson.

PORT
This game was ported by Rockstar Seeds who were known for porting other pc games either developed or published by Rockstar such as GTA 4. Team Bondi developed this game for Xbox 360 and Ps3 and a year later, Rockstar Seeds brought it to PC. Like GTA 4, LA Noire isn't really that a good a port, maybe worst if you ask me. There's no mod support so there's nothing anybody can do fix the issues this game has. The PC controls aren't that well so you need a controller. The framerate is capped at 30fps, unless you use the tool I mentioned above, it's easy to use. However some of the physics in the game will be messed up when playing at 60fps, there are videos on Youtube that shows it. But just cap it back to 30fps for a minute and you'll be fine. Also there are plenty of texture pop-ins everywhere you look especially driving. It's obvious that it is a console port.

GRAPHICS
As stated there are a ton of texture and assets popping up in the screen but you can handle after a little while. The amount of detail in this game is amazing. As a guy who lives in Los Angeles, I actually recognized a lot of buildings in the game, the amount of work put into the interior, and exterior design of the city is beautiful. As you may know, this game utilizes what's called MotionScan, where the developers used 32 high definition cameras to capture actors faces. While it looks great, less attention I believed was put into the bodies since it was done separately.

STORY
You start as a cop, then rise to becoming a detective. The story is told by the cases you solve, however the actual story to the game does start later near the end when you're in vice. You can pick up the pieces to the story by picking up newspapers as you're doing the earlier cases. The dialogue in this game is well written but there were some times when I felt that the actors where overdoing it. Above all, the story is really good and dark since that's what you would expect from the noire type of entertainment.

GAMEPLAY
Rockstar may have published this game but it doesn't mean you blast gas stations up with a rocket launcher. To simply put, the gameplay is extremely limiting. You can browse the open world detail of LA Noire but there isn't much to do in this game when not doing the cases. There are mini side quests where help people out but they're really short (Lasts about 1-3 minutes). Interrogation in this game consists of asking a question and wondering if that person's telling a truth or lieing and expose them with evidence, or doubt them if you don't believe them. Like other Rockstar games, there are gunplay but in my honest opinion the gunplay in this game feels like an arcade game. It's not the same as GTA or Red Dead Redemption's gunplay which I think is amazing (Rockstar please bring to PC).

CONCLUSION
I believe you will enjoy this game especially when getting the Complete Edition which has every case the game has to offer. I know I haven't said much about your character Cole Phelps but to honest he has no personality at all. You don't know much about him in a personal level. Kind of like Dark Souls (But not really, bare with me)
1.) Port isn't that good (30fps lock)
2.) Environment is really well detailed and amazing
3,) Don't know much about the character you play as.

If on sale, get this game and have fun, it's a long game.

reviewText:
Love the visuals. The voice acting and usage of facial implementation in this game is outstanding. Having a setting in the 1940s Los Angeles really works well for a free-roaming detective story.

The gameplay can be tricky at times, especially with a gamepad. If you're not used to shooting with lock features, it may lead to frustration.

Because of said visuals, it can really show its difficulty when it comes to investigations and interviews, as it is a factor: collecting clues, getting information from witnesses, all to get a perfect case performance. You're not supposed to rely completely on memory to succeed, but rather your awareness on scenes, faces and possible evidence.

There's no trigger happy experience for Grand Theft Auto or Postal fans. It seems that the branded cars, food products and other memorable landmarks in the city are the spotlights of the game.

reviewText: Fantastic detective game with a very enjoyable story, characters that are interesting, some of the best facial animations yet, a wonderful creation of old school LA and the detective gameplay is a TON of fun. The game is not as open world as say GTA or Watch Dogs, but it goes for story alot more and also has the great detective work, looking for clues, interviewing people about crimes and trying to figure out if they are lying or telling the truth. If you want more story/character driven game pick this up, more linear than most open world games but the fantastic detecitve work, story, characters and animations are top notch. The game is capped at 30fps because of the facial animations they use, which might annoy some people, but once you play you will see it is not a big deal. Didn't have any crashes in the game and no big game breaking bugs. Not perfect but overall I had a blast on this game the two times I beat it. Not the best graphics ever but as I said the animations are fantastic and most everything else is well done.\n\nLooking for a fun detective game? Pick this up asap!

reviewText:
A masterpiece falling short.

Had a long think about this review. The technology is nothing short of breathtaking and well worth it as a tour de force of what great tech can add to a game.

The gameplay feature of reading the charactors tells is, i think, a great inovation and also, a difficult whip to crack. It can feel a little lopsided as some of the acting i over egged and thus paints the conversion as somewhat bipolar.
Although this could of been negated by yet more acting, I can understand that the complexity of such would of either burnt out the actors or moved the game into a different year for completion.

I've heard of the heartache associated with the production of the game and can understand why. Its easy to dismiss when coming from a place of ignorance with some of those slight bugs but when looked at as a whole, the game broke some ground, not only in gameplay but technology aswell, not to mention tying them together. I applaud the huge undertaking this game was.

One thing that was a little underwhelming though.....the driving... its not a driving game as we already know, its really a detective game but the driving elements, for me, could of been more fun with you being driven around rather than do the driving. I like driving games but when the driving is profuctory rather than part of the game, its best left out. Would of really enjoyed being driven around and take in the sights, scouting for suspects etc....perhaps have a little gun fight along the way etc. I think that would of lended better to a detective game than a sort of limited driving sim with lowend mechanics.

Last thoughts, although the main portion of development missed the driving aspects its understandable when you have such attention paid to a rather breathtaking level of charactor detail and nuance.

reviewText:
Usually I try to finish the games I start as quickly as possible. I do the side quests, I try some achievements, but before playing any other game I try to finish what I started. That’s not the case with LA Noire: I avoid playing it. Why? Because it is in another league completely. The game is so good I’m taking my time to finish it. Literally MONTHS. I simply don’t want to end the story too quickly, I’m sipping it.
The graphics are amazing, playing in 1080p with ‘quality’ settings and DX11 is an incredible experience. On the downside, there’s a 30fps lock, but that doesn’t compromise the gameplay because the action isn’t frantic. I find the game to be historically accurate as well. It definitely portrays the beginning of the American “Golden Age” (check the “Old Economy Steven” MEME for further references) in a clear-cut manner. There’s a “Bukowskian” atmosphere surrounding the setting and the characters (Bukowski was living in Los Angeles during the 40’s and both “Ham on Rye” and “Factotum” are accurate descriptions of that period). Coincidence or not, there’s a character in the game named “Bekowsky”...
The characters are cynical, disillusioned, smoking drunkards, racist sexist ♥♥♥♥♥♥, and the “noir femme fatales” shares many of the features of the male characters. LA is portrayed as a XX century Babylonian city packed with all sorts of lowlifes, degenerates, powerful and perverted directors and producers (L.A. didn't changed all that much, huh?). Due to its dedication to the Noir genre the game ends up rated Mature. This definitely isn’t a game for young gents. There’s plenty of nudity in some crime scenes, and the developers don’t hide anything, which is great, otherwise the game couldn’t qualify as a proper Noir-detective title.
Since I have already established that this game is a marvelous piece of art, let’s see the cons:
•	30 fps lock.
•	Rockstar Social Club is required to play the game.
•	The aforementioned Rockstar Social Club will eventually request your password, and you won’t remember it because the password needs to be 300 characters long, with 20 special characters, numbers and 125 capital letters. Why? Why??
•	Every time you update the Rockstar Social Club, which is mandatory, otherwise the game won’t start… it’ll request your password again. And guess what: that 300 characters password you created 4 months ago won’t work because YOU WON’T REMEMBER IT. And when you request to reset it, all sorts of issues are going to popup. Seriously, you can count on it.
•	Rockstar Social Club again. It’s useless. It’s dead weight and it’s sadistic towards the gamers. Steam offers everything a gamer needs, we don’t need extra-layers of crappy proprietary-software between us and the fun. It’s some sort of annoyance toll.
•	Rockstar Social Club is worse than Uplay . There, I said it.

Other than that the game is a 10/10.

reviewText:
Let's start with the graphics. For starters I was actually amazed that L.A. Noire was the first console game that had near-flawless if not flawless anti-aliasing. I kid you not, you could take a look at the telephone wires from up close or from afar and there would be no jaggies. Nevertheless, I attempted to convince myself that my mind was playing tricks on me and that some anti-alised objects were just polished to perfection. I was partially right; it's only the telephone wires, cars and some other objects that have no jaggies.

The graphics settings for the PC version are:

Antialiasing: 1-3
Anisotropic Filtering: 1-4
Ambient Occlusion - Yes/No
Facial Quality - Quality/Performance
Texture Quality - Quality/Performance
Shadow Quality - Quality/Performance/Balanced
Lighting Quality - Quality/Performance/Balanced
Environment Map - Quality/Performance/Balanced
Level of Detail Quality - Quality/Performance/Balanced
Screen Space Ambient Occlusion - On/Off
Global Detail Level - Quality/Performance/Balanced

And there's also a command line for various set-up options.

If you have a high end PC you can get 30 FPS if you pick all Quality.
However, if you choose Performance, you ALSO get 30 FPS.

So they converted the game to PC yet they forgot to raise the FPS cap, hmmm weird. Honestly, I did not notice much difference between the PS3 and the PC version graphic-wise. I mean all those extra graphics options are nice for the ego-boost but I had a hard time telling the difference especially with the frequent texture popping.

What I mean is that the game's graphics suffer immensely when you drive your vehicle for instance. Objects just pop out of thin air and grow out of the ground slowly enough for you to notice. You may drive and look ahead at some of the box-like buildings when all of a sudden they begin to acquire the necessary features such as windows, doors, color, etc.

Also, in many instances the game practically plays by itself. Again, that was done with the controller movement in mind. You may run after someone through the rooftops, fire escape ladders, alleyways and what not and be automatically redirected to pursue the suspect. The game GUIDES you forces you after the suspect because it assumes you may not be able to make that sharp turn with your controller; all you'll have to hold is the forward" button.

-----
Part 2

Make no mistake

reviewText:
This is really quite sad example of how the game industry sometimes works. The game may not be on the top shelf of quality, barely fitting 'the solid-good' one. And yet it IS a good game. And not in the way of 'guilty pleasure' good, no. This title is a great example of a sereis in which the second one corrects every mistake of the first one.

Unfortunatelly we do not have the possibility to play second one and we are left with this flawed piece of a 'sketch'. And whilst it is a quite nice idea for a drawing, it is not by any means perfect one. Starting with a mediocre graphics, very hard to rate depending on which side we are looking at (faces and interiors are really nice, the rest is... meh). The gameplay is I'd say quite poor and very repetitive.

And yet this title took more than 20 hours of my life. And I do not regret it at all. Because as far as the plot, the character, the music adn the climat goes the game is just outstanding! I could really, (without any problems whatsoever) close an eye on a technical side in this case. Take it without a hesitation if you are the player for whom the story development is more important than a gameplay. Especially if you liked the Sabouteur and you are keen on the 40s, noire, and jazz

reviewText:
Okay let us get started with this.
This game has a great story, amazing gameplay, stupendous voice acting and outstanding facial animations. One of the best games out there along with GTA 5. This game is a pure classic.

HOWEVER, HOWEVER, HOWEVER, there is one thing about L.A. Noire that pisses me off tremendously. The game is capped at 30 frames per second. As a PC gamer with a powerful rig, this pisses me off because i play most of my games (90% of them) at 60 fps and higher. Playing at 30 fps did not seem right at all. It feels sluggish, and it does not look smooth at all (to me at least).

Nonetheless, you can uncap the framerate by using WideScreenFixer. You will be able to play it at 60 fps if your PC is powerful enough but then uncapping the framerate would mess up one thing. The driving. Driving is one of the key elements of this game and after you have uncapped the framerate, driving physics will be slightly altered. It will be harder to drive around as the vehicle will feel floaty" like how the driving in GTA 4 feels like. But if you can get used to that
date: then there should not be a problem at all.\n\nThat would be the only issue in this game so if you can overcome it
recommended: you will have a great experience playing it. I would definitely persuade anyone out there to purchase L.A. Noire."

reviewText:
Really incredible. The game play itself isn't anything spectacular, but the world that Rockstar has created in 1947 Los Angeles is really something to experience.

I have spent hours just driving around, sightseeing, listening to the radio, finding various secrets. My dad lived in L.A. In the mid 50s, so I got to share a bit of his youthful memories through the game. He even recognized the song playing on the radio!

An interesting side note: Rockstar used over 180,000 aerial photographs in order to more accurately reproduce that noire feeling of 1940s Los Angeles. Actual radio broadcasts, commercials, and music (The Bickersons, The Jack Benny Program, Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald) were also used to further immerse the player.

A fun game, but if you're at all into 40s Americana it's worth buying just to cruise down Holywood Blvd in one of the 95 vintage cars listening to Bing Crosby.

I certainly enjoyed it!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I like this game mostly because the new things they tried to do, were done right. BUT, there are other things that should have been done better, basically because somebody else has already done them right.

+ Acting, both faces and voices, are excellent and interviews are quite fun.
+ The cases are interesting, altough sometimes a bit predictable and linear. Sometimes you say things you souldn t have known (because you missed that clue before or changed the order in wich you do something) and thats quite odd, I d really like there where different ways to solve a case or even fail it. There is some of that, but it doesn t really work that way (DLCs do it a bit better )

- But what I like the least about this game is combat. I realise it is very story driven and you can skip action parts if you fail them a few times, but that s not an excuse for faulty controls. Usually they are not a mess, but just sloppy enough to get into my nerves from time to time. Like when you just stand there eating bullets instead of getting into cover, or running into walls while chasing a suspect.

- I d like it existed the chance to go for peaceful solutions to some cases (street crimes for instance), like trying to talk a barricated suspect into surrendering instead of just shoting them.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire took me really long to complete with all the DLC, around 40 hours and it was hell of a run.

This game was filled with amazing detective based mystery cases and a very distinct story line.

The action was fun and amusing, chasing down people on foot and inside the vehicles. The gun action was also basic and easy to understand , from taking cover to blind firing your ememies or even just straight ramboing it.

Taking the vehicles back to 1940's was a very neat idea, driving old cars was fun for a change wrather than the ones in the GTA series. They are over 90 vehicles and I only found half of them.

The map is huge and there's just so much to explore.

The main factor of the game is the motion capture of the face, the facial expressions were probably the most detailed and realistic I've ever seen in a game. When it comes to asking questions, i'm sure many people will get stumped or unsure on either choosing the truth"
date:
"doubt" or a "lie"

I will give this game 9/10
just because the ending wasn't how I wanted it to end."

reviewText:
I got this game expecting a noir-themed detective game, with a intuitive investigating and interrogation mechanic. It was those things, sure, but it was also a cover-based shooter.

Ugh.

The cover-based shooting is sort of alright. There are worse, but when you go from thoughtful investigation to YET ANOTHER BLOODY CHASE SCENE is really jarring the first few times.

I would recommend this game if you want to learn how to manipulate others and have a passing interest in body language and psychology; it's here, and here in tons. If you can wade past the seemingly mandatory sludge of cover-based shooting.

Used a fruit machine and a box of drugs appeared/10

reviewText:
It's like playing a movie, in the best way imaginable.

I've seen previews of it, and I was intrigued. I heard more about it and I really got interested. I saw someone demo it and I was immediately sold.

This game is not for everyone, however. It has gritty visuals and intense subject matter. If you like the Black Dahlia film or Noir detective stories, you may like this.

The sound direction is superb, and the music is very well done. Some tracks can wear on the nerves, but the action tracks put you in the moment.

This game plays very well on Windows 7, but crashes do happen on occasion.

Overall, this is a very excellent title, and the actors are superb, for the most part. If you watch Mad Men, you may see more familiar faces than just Phelps. This is a huge leap for in-game visuals, as the talking heads do look very good most of the time. Some glitches can be jarring, but they're few.

It's a large game, and requres a lot of RAM and a very capable video card. Nevertheless, it's well worth the visit to 1940's Los Angeles if you want a good detective procedural.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire took me really long to complete with all the DLC, around 40 hours and it was hell of a run.

This game was filled with amazing detective based mystery cases and a very distinct story line.

The action was fun and amusing, chasing down people on foot and inside the vehicles. The gun action was also basic and easy to understand , from taking cover to blind firing your ememies or even just straight ramboing it.

Taking the vehicles back to 1940's was a very neat idea, driving old cars was fun for a change wrather than the ones in the GTA series. They are over 90 vehicles and I only found half of them.

The map is huge and there's just so much to explore.

The main factor of the game is the motion capture of the face, the facial expressions were probably the most detailed and realistic I've ever seen in a game. When it comes to asking questions, i'm sure many people will get stumped or unsure on either choosing the truth"
date:
"doubt" or a "lie"

I will give this game 9/10
just because the ending wasn't how I wanted it to end."

reviewText: This is yet another masterpiece of a game delivered by Rockstar. The addition of 'real' facial expressions may seem a bit gimmicky but is essential when questioning suspects. It is up to the game player to determine whether suspects are telling the truth or lying, and this can be done by carefully watching facial expressions. However, if you accuse a suspect of lying you will need to have some kind of proof to back it up. Graphically, the developers has done an amazing job - there does not seem to be a noticable repetition of buildings within the map. Vehicles are rendered beautifully and appear to be fairly faithful to the real things. It is a shame that the game is limited to 30fps on the PC but it is a solid 30fps (played with Fraps running to check). The XBox 360 version has moments where the FPS drops well below 30. Sound is used very well, using a dramatic score when something important is happening in the game. Music is also used during the searching of clues and helps the game player stay within the 'search area'. NPCs have dialogue but it can be quite repetitive. Sound effects are spot on, even down to the sound of aircraft flying high up overhead and chirping birds, etc.\n\nL.A. Noire will appeal to gamers who like to think and solves clues. It may appear to be similar to the GTA series but the missions are in no way similar. If you are an arcade game fan this game will not appeal as it is very difficult to pick it up for a quick blast.

reviewText:
This game is underrated, but it is suprisingly an amazing game.
In L.A. Noire you're playing as a cop that goes by the name of Cole Phelps. The game takes place
in 1940's Los Angeles and I think the game developers did an amazing job creating this game. During the
time you play the game you really get that feeling that the city is supposed to be 1940's L.A., when almost everyone wore a suit and a hat!

Also, the facial expressions in this game is amazing. Too bad they haven't used this technique in other games.
The PC-port for this game has been criticized, and I agree that the PC-port could be alot better.
However, the game itself is amazing, the PC-port doesn't ruin the experience of playing the game, in my opinion.

reviewText: A great experiment with mixed results, the use of face capture technology is very impressive but probably won't age well. Tying the unique tech to an interrogation mechanic is a great idea, though sometimes the interrogations themselves can be frustrating and illogical, even to the point that I'd just restart the mission if it became a wash. Shooting and driving are both passable and functional, except for a frustrating sequence in the finale which involves way more shooting than the rest of the game.\n\nWhat I love most about this game is its adherence to Noir style, complete with all the backstabbing intrigue that comes with it. Nearly every Noir trope is in full effect here, and there's some truly excellent acting to be found, on par with Hollywood productions, probably because there are a great deal of talented character actors involved that you'll probably recognize from this thing or that. The story is solid and kept me hooked, and its final scene is brilliantly delivered. As with others I've enjoyed, this is a game I recommend not for the strength of its mechanics, but for its feel"
date: and in terms of making you feel like a hard-boiled Noir detective
recommended: you won't find anything better on the market."

reviewText: Note: Review based on console version. Don't let the low play time fool you!\n\nLA Noire is a wonderful experience in gaming. There aren't many games like this out there, which is a shame. Take on the role of a Police officer in post WWII Los Angeles. The city has been lovingly re-created with all the streets and famous landmarks. However, don't expect a GTA style sandbox; this game is very linear and all about the main story. Also, while the city has been expertly crafted, you won't be given much reason to explore it; no non-mission specific buildings are able to be entered and there is very little to no interactivity with anything in the city. Getting past those faults though, this is a great detective game with a unique twist. You must read the facial expressions of the people you interogate and make assumptions based on that. While this doesn't always work smoothly, it's super cool trying to read the characters and try and tell if they're lying or not. This game also has a great style. If you couldn't tell, it's a classic Noire style presentation and can even be played in black and white (recommended for that legitimate noire feel). This game is not for everyone. It can be slow and after finishing the game, some may not want to replay missions when they already know whodunnit. If it does pique your interest though, pick this up on sale.
