reviewText:
A great game that has an interesting setting and gameplay mechanic.

The game world is based around post-WWII LA.  The story is focused around detective work on various cases that range from traffic crimes, to homicide, to arson, and vice cases.  Each case has clues you have to discover as the scene and from the various people you question about the case.  Finding more clues gives you more options in questioning.  The question mechanics involves you paying attention to how the person acts, basically you’re trying to tell if they did the crime, had a part in it, or are innocent.  This mechanic also extends to trying to get information out of some people, i.e. do you gently try get more information or go on the aggressive and force them to tell you.  The better you do at questioning and clue finding will result in a higher case score.

If you have trouble questioning people there are points you can spend to either narrow the choices or if you’re online can see what the majority did.  These points are earned through various success levels on completion of a case, i.e. the better you do the more points you get.

The cases are divided into the various desks you work at while on the force.  Each desk also represents a promotion in rank on the force.  Due to the theme of the game some of these cases can be extremely graphic and like with the age and culture your dealing with the language can also be mature.

Gameplay involves you or your partner driving to the scene of the crime.  If you drive you'll be able to do side missions, street crimes, that come in from dispatch while you’re on the road.  These street crimes are not the best element of the game as they mostly have you running and gunning down criminals, they get repetitive quickly.  Once at the scene of the crime you’re able to look for clues and get information from other characters (other officers, the coroner, and witnesses), from there it tracking down leads, questioning people, and the occasional car chase.

Overall, the game does provide a unique experience and is definitely worth picking up.  However, you should buy the Complete Edition as it adds a number of cases that extend gameplay, without them, I wouldn't advise picking up the game.  The reason is because there are some desks that don't have many cases and the additional content adds a lot more meat to the game.

If you don’t own the game and see it on for a 75% off or higher sale I’d highly recommend picking it up.  Game length would be about 40-50 hours if you do most or all of what it has to offer.

reviewText: [7/10] – L.A. Noire is a very entertaining action detective simulator that has incredible attention to detail and a phenomenal animation system. Yet sadly, its 30fps cap, and dodgy controls at times leave a small void inside me. Even with its flaws, it’s a very fun and mature title, and worth the price of admission. If you like GTA/Mafia II style open world games, but want the intellectualism offered only by more mature titles, then this is for you. It definitely makes you think, and punishes you for poor detective skills, so good problem solving is a must. There are also some pretty awesome action moments with a Hollywood feel to them, and usually don’t disappoint. Overall I thought it was a good ride while it lasted.

reviewText: Play as a detective in post war L.A. and solve multiple cases. The characters' facial animations have been done in a totally new way and it looks superb. Their expressions change realistically according to what they are saying and in what context or mood they are in. Surely all the software developers are going to have to use this technique with their characters from now on? Just having lip syncing without facial expressions won't cut it anymore after this.\nThe game itself is original and compelling. I can't think of another game anything like it. I can't believe that it appears that there is no sequel in the works either! It will be a great shame if there's no follow up.\nBrilliant and totally original.

reviewText: The year 1947 the case The Red Lipstick Murder"
date: a woman is found murdered and brutally beaten then dumped at a park just across the LAPD Police Station. Your job as a new dectective is to scout the scene
hoursPlayed: find the suspects and interogate them using your intuition and facts to chase down the killer. This is just one example of fantastic cases that you have to figure out and bring down the killers and criminals who commit crimes across L.A.\nYou play as Phelps
voteText: a World War 2 veteran and all around do-gooder. Phelps is an honest man who has a strict honor system and puts his all into a case that he is working on. Phelps starts out as a common on the beat cop who likes to put his nose where it usually doesnt belong. He quickly excells through the ranks and without giving any spoilers he becomes a hero cop and is promoted to detective on the trafiic cases. I find this incredibly interesting since you dont immediately start out as this recognized protaganist in a game filled with crime and criminals. But these guys and gals you come across in L.A arent people you really expect to be murders and rapists. These people are your average run of the mill
helpfulPercent:
hard working citizens who just try to make a living in the city.
But looks are deceiving. Some of the citizens are actually complete psychopaths!
While the core story is really interesting the gameplay is somewhat lacking and the visuals if inspected have small bugs. I found on serveral occasions that some doors i tied walking through would sometimes bug and stay perma shut until i restarted the game. I dont know if that was a problem with my PC or just in general a problem. However I have never encountered it another game. Anyway combat reminds me alot of Red Dead and they are made by the same developer so it was good to see that the combat was very detailed and carefully made. Combat really only comes into play every now and then so if you are a gamer that needs tons of action L.A Noire is not for you.
Gamers with patience and pay very close attention to facts and facial expressions will succed in L.A Noire on some occasions. (there is a part where you have to deal with an actress

reviewText: Do you love crime dramas? How about those old school Noire films you can find on Netflix? Well then this game is going to be a treat for you ! Even if you are not a huge crime drama fan, La Norie is still made by Rockstar so there's plenty of things from the story to the gameplay that will keep you hooked until the very end. You play as Cole Phelps, a military veteran that returned to LA as a police officer. You solve cases and go up in ranks. Each case as a unqiue twist and all need speical attention if you want to get the right guy. If you ever thought about how cool it would be to work as a detective than do yourself a favor and pick up this game !

reviewText:

reviewText: L.A. Noire is a fantastic game. I personally give it a 10/10. Because it has a fantastic story that is unparalleled even in today's movies and books. The game play is amazing, and to be honest im gonna leave it towards other people to go on about that. I just wanted to put my peice out there saying that this game is worth your money.\n\nBut also because i wanted to end all the claims of how bad a port it really is. Yes it is not the best port, but compared to  GTA IV and its GFWL port, it's pretty damn good. People saying 30fps is a con are just wrong, flat out wrong. People need to put it under a plus. 30fps is so smooth in this game, because the engine was NOT designed for 60fps. I myself have played about half an hour at an uncapped 60fps and i couldn't go on any longer, while yes it looks smooth as ♥♥♥♥, the driving is horrible, like driving on a ice skating rink and the brakes don't work, and the facial animations look worse, they look really stupid and to quote the infamous console peasant cry 60fps is too fast"
date:
it is only applicable to L.A. Noire.

To fix the framerate though because it does have trouble keeping a solid 30fps. Copy and paste this in your command line in the launch options.

-npd -str -nonv

It works for most people

reviewText:
This game cured my porn addiction during the Homicide cases! 10/10 No doubt!

However, there are in-fact downsides... Even if you do have a computer capable playing Grand Theft Auto IV, you may still suffer very bad gameplay experience because of its limited 30 frames per second refresh rate and some other technical bits about the bad performance of the game...

Since this game is not using Rockstar's Advanced Game Engine but a modified unnamed engine, I guess you may find that some driving aspects and shooting mechanics are slight different in the works from GTA IV...

Workarounds are of course limited and not throughly proven to fix all solutions surrounding the game, example:
-str or Single Threading game setting
-nonv to disable nVidia 3D stereoscopic view (if you are using AMD or Intel GPU)
-npd works by extending the compatibilty of GPUs which are not in their native supported DirectX version. If you have a DirectX 10 GPU but there's no DX10 option, you better choose DirectX 9 renderer and add -npd to the command line

But if you managed to iron out (or even ignored) these NG stuffs, you will really get to experience the game at it's best!

Played on an Intel Pentium Dual Core processor PC with 2GB RAM and Intel HD Graphics with some drawbacks.

reviewText: I haven't finished it yet, but I'm going to recommend it anyway. This game represents a breakthrough in a certain type of realism in a 3D game - a truly realistic, largely seamless translation of actors' faces into the virtual environment. The main gameplay element is reading other people to a degree that requires attention to their faces, achieving a new level of immersion worth experiencing. The rest of the game is also very well made. A few graphical deficiencies can be overlooked. The game seems to run fairly well for a console port.

reviewText: A very enjoyable game if you like story-based gameplay, almost like playing Ace Attorney but in 3D and with probably the best facial animations there have been or will be for some time in video games. The setting is perfect, recreating 1940s LA down to the fashion, music, and nuances of the time. Well worth it's ~30hr playtime including the DLC, which comes in the Complete Edition and should be the version to get if you are considering buying the game.

reviewText:
You're one of the LA's finest, a former military veteran who is looking to build a successful career out of law enforcement in 1940's post World War II L.A. with fancy suits and muscle cars. It's men's world.

Playing L.A. Noire is like taking part in an interactive movie. It's more than just watching the action as you get to take part in it. And the outcome of the cases is determined on your gut, your attention to detail, and interrogation skills rather than just wating the actor to state their line. If there is at least a tiny bit of detective in you and you want to get to the bottom of things then you'll find the storyline captivating and it will drag you in like honey.

As of gameplay, mouse & keyboard combo is tolerable. Walking and running around with keys and using mouse to look/aim works fine most of the time. Driving is slightly awkward when you want to drive straight or especially when trying to take sharp corners in high speed due to the fact that the camera turns slowly behind the vehicle unless your mouse hand is in sync with your keyboard hand. Many times I've ended up smashing bumpers with oncoming traffic or rear fender taking contact with nearby mailbox or lamp post. However, as this is not the most important mechanic I bare with it. Car chases are still fun.

Interrogation of people is the one that gives you the most what ifs". Do I believe what this person is saying with their eyes rolling out of their heads or do I push my luck to squeeze the last bit of information they have? Or do I dare to state they're lying and then provide them with evidence that I know what the real case is? And you'd better have the evidence with such allegation or the conversation may be short lived.

The gameplay involves occasional chases both on foot and on wheels
date: some gunfights and brawls. They play out decently not getting too much attention from the story itself. In overall
recommended: there's a nice balance of action
hoursPlayed: seeking and dialogue to my taste and it keeps me tempted to replay a case after a case until I get the gist of how it should have been.\n\nIf you have no patience and you couldn't care less about the story then this might not be the game for you. But if you're into the era and the mysteries of police detectives then I highly recommend L.A. Noire."

reviewText: If you’re like me, and enjoy a film-like narrative in a videogame, this is the game for you. The writing is phenomenal, the amount and variety of cases you come across too. It’s a huge game, that took me something like 50 hours to clear. However, you have to come into it aware that the game mechanics are somewhat of a bore. The vastness of the story elements contrasts with the limited gameplay. The open city is a good thing, the cars and such too, but if you’re expecting Rockstar’s GTA controls and gameplay, you’ll be disappointed.

reviewText: Play as a detective in post war L.A. and solve multiple cases. The characters' facial animations have been done in a totally new way and it looks superb. Their expressions change realistically according to what they are saying and in what context or mood they are in. Surely all the software developers are going to have to use this technique with their characters from now on? Just having lip syncing without facial expressions won't cut it anymore after this.\nThe game itself is original and compelling. I can't think of another game anything like it. I can't believe that it appears that there is no sequel in the works either! It will be a great shame if there's no follow up.\nBrilliant and totally original.

reviewText: The year 1947 the case The Red Lipstick Murder"

voteText: a World War 2 veteran and all around do-gooder. Phelps is an honest man who has a strict honor system and puts his all into a case that he is working on. Phelps starts out as a common on the beat cop who likes to put his nose where it usually doesnt belong. He quickly excells through the ranks and without giving any spoilers he becomes a hero cop and is promoted to detective on the trafiic cases. I find this incredibly interesting since you dont immediately start out as this recognized protaganist in a game filled with crime and criminals. But these guys and gals you come across in L.A arent people you really expect to be murders and rapists. These people are your average run of the mill

reviewText: [7/10] – L.A. Noire is a very entertaining action detective simulator that has incredible attention to detail and a phenomenal animation system. Yet sadly, its 30fps cap, and dodgy controls at times leave a small void inside me. Even with its flaws, it’s a very fun and mature title, and worth the price of admission. If you like GTA/Mafia II style open world games, but want the intellectualism offered only by more mature titles, then this is for you. It definitely makes you think, and punishes you for poor detective skills, so good problem solving is a must. There are also some pretty awesome action moments with a Hollywood feel to them, and usually don’t disappoint. Overall I thought it was a good ride while it lasted.

reviewText: Fantastic game. It really has this feel of 40s to it, which I enjoyed very much. The main characters and the story are really interesting, well written and, with the outstanding facial animations, you can really attach to them. Interrogating is cool, but unfortunately isn't always very intuitive. But I still loved the game and the L.A. in late 40s.

reviewText: Superb writing and storyline, has the quality that rivals top films and TV shows. Amazing periodic atmosphere, cast is stunning (most of the actors are in mad men) and the banter between Phelps and his partners is gold. Phelps' character has so much depth and is one of the rare video game characters that you can invest in emotionally/connect with (another parallel with great film/television). An example of what games should be if they are to be taken seriously, instead of all the crappy no-story, arcade/FPS/MMO/lookatallthedifferentwaysicankilleveryone games that crowd the marketplace. One of the best games of all time.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a lot like an adventure game, but it's very original and doesn't spare any novelty for that. I found it very enjoyable, a game full of mystery, with a well written story and interesting characters. Action is well done likewise, but it isn't the main focus of the game, instead it's the process of solving a case, finding the truth even though the harder you go, the harder it is. The whole facial animations are great, in fact there are no animations - the facial expressions are taken from real people. Unfortunately it can fall in the Uncanny Valley at times, but you can't blame it for that since, it's trying to succeed. If there would be no initiative - there would be no success.

This is a favourite of mine.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=48474200

reviewText:
A portal to a bygone era. One thing that Rockstar and Team Bondi have accomplished here is a genuine level of authenticity that is unparalleled in most AAA games these days. Due to their unique approach to facial animation capture, utilizing a real-time performance from their voice actors, the developers have been able to tap into an unprecedented gameplay mechanic:

The player's ability to read human expression.

This mechanic sets the title apart from any other game that has ever been made and singlehandedly makes the title a must play. It's truly a shame that we won't be seeing a continuation of this IP in the future, it would have been neat to have stories set in other cities like NY or Chicago.

reviewText:
I powered through L.A. Noire because I enjoyed the story and I found each case to be compelling.  The way it weaved the past into current events and tied things together by the end was legendary.  The way the devs captured the actor's facial expressions, while treading into the uncanny valley big-time, gave this game an amazing quality.  Driving through old time Los Angeles was a lot of fun.  I think this is a game most people will enjoy.

All that being said sometimes when characters talk their mouths look really wrong.  It looks like the mesh is the wrong shape for the expression ( usually noticable with yelling and other large mouth shapes).  While historically accurate all the cars look way too much alike to necessate the diversity in this game (especially with the frustrating achievement attached to driving them all).  Getting in and out of cars takes flippin' forever.  Special cars that boast a max speed of 140 MPH even at full throtle the game says your max speed even was around 86 MPH.

The main gameplay element of interrigation is frustrating as they purposefully designed it to not allow you to restart a bad interrigation over without quitting and reloading your last save.  Sure, it opens other opportunities to play through the mission based on failure to catch the person in a lie but that wasn't what I was playing this for.

Story gripes ahead, Spoilers: The love interest in this game looks like a dirty bag of melted action figures so when Cole started persuing her romatically I didn't buy it for a second.  You are a war hero get a woman that is worth the trouble. The ending was purposefully unsatisfying but come on give a guy some hope that Cole's work wasn't for nothing.

reviewText:
What can i say? after a couple of hours playing this game, i just fell completely in love with it.

Imagine freedom as in GTA. But as a cop. An honest cop.
Get your case assignments, try to be as honest and good as possible. Question suspects and witnesses. Decide who's lying or telling the truth. Search for clues at crime scenes.

Go and assist other crimes. Or just don't. Be a good boy and run after your fleeing suspects, or shoot them down.
Drive carefully, or be a gung-ho.

It's all up to you.

The character conversations are incredible. The lip-sync used in this, is just the best i've ever seen. At the beginning, i had to just open a browser, and confirm if that voice was Liam Neeson's. It was.

Whatever you do.. Buy this game.

reviewText:
Another Rockstar so immersion is outstanding, again play with headphones.  The feel of, I'm guessing, 1950s LA is tremendous and is really remeniscent of LA Confidential, so I instantly loved this.

The voice acting is really well done indeed and I'm guessing the actors bodies were imaged for each character in this, so it's a big bravo on that.  The story is very impressive and it was excellent to see the main plot ticking over in the background whilst you're following a meandering path, which will eventually lead you to said plot.  The graphics and sound effects were excellent and joined with the innovative element of interrogation you have a winning formula that deserves to be a big fan favourite.  Also hats off to attention to detail with the vehicles.  They had no crumple zones and such in those days, as they were just girders on wheels and if you hit something you really hit it with a crunch.

If you don't have this then get it.

9/10

reviewText: My overall impression of the game is - it should have been done differently. Even though I enjoyed its setting and atmosphere, I can't help but think that there are so many things that could have been improved - such as the storytelling (after 35 hours of gameplay I still can't say that I fully understand the main character's motivations) or graphics (beautifully done faces plastered on fake looking bodies didn't exactly work for me). The city is unnecessarily big and, sadly, feels quite empty. Perhaps the game would have been better off without the forced sandbox feel. However, I enjoyed the majority of the cases and would deffinitely want something similar to be developed in the future - just without the aforementioned faults. I'd rate L.A. Noire 7 out of 10 - even with all its small issues, the game managed to hook me for the whole 35 hours. I don't think I will come back to it though; it's just a one-time experience.

reviewText:
A great game that has an interesting setting and gameplay mechanic.

The game world is based around post-WWII LA.  The story is focused around detective work on various cases that range from traffic crimes, to homicide, to arson, and vice cases.  Each case has clues you have to discover as the scene and from the various people you question about the case.  Finding more clues gives you more options in questioning.  The question mechanics involves you paying attention to how the person acts, basically you’re trying to tell if they did the crime, had a part in it, or are innocent.  This mechanic also extends to trying to get information out of some people, i.e. do you gently try get more information or go on the aggressive and force them to tell you.  The better you do at questioning and clue finding will result in a higher case score.

If you have trouble questioning people there are points you can spend to either narrow the choices or if you’re online can see what the majority did.  These points are earned through various success levels on completion of a case, i.e. the better you do the more points you get.

The cases are divided into the various desks you work at while on the force.  Each desk also represents a promotion in rank on the force.  Due to the theme of the game some of these cases can be extremely graphic and like with the age and culture your dealing with the language can also be mature.

Gameplay involves you or your partner driving to the scene of the crime.  If you drive you'll be able to do side missions, street crimes, that come in from dispatch while you’re on the road.  These street crimes are not the best element of the game as they mostly have you running and gunning down criminals, they get repetitive quickly.  Once at the scene of the crime you’re able to look for clues and get information from other characters (other officers, the coroner, and witnesses), from there it tracking down leads, questioning people, and the occasional car chase.

Overall, the game does provide a unique experience and is definitely worth picking up.  However, you should buy the Complete Edition as it adds a number of cases that extend gameplay, without them, I wouldn't advise picking up the game.  The reason is because there are some desks that don't have many cases and the additional content adds a lot more meat to the game.

If you don’t own the game and see it on for a 75% off or higher sale I’d highly recommend picking it up.  Game length would be about 40-50 hours if you do most or all of what it has to offer.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Worth it to look at the motion capture tech used, it really shows how much similar the in-game models are to the real actors( If you don't believe it, see this http://i.chzbgr.com/completestore/2011/6/6/bef7a093-eaee-4ae7-90f1-7b47f89775b5.jpg ). Every animation is more complex than you will see in most games, some sequences will seem like you are watching a live-action movie. It's different from your average GTA/sandbox game(in fact, not much to explore at all), as you will mostly just do your detective work. Interrogating suspects, searching for clues, still ends up being to easy most of the time, the 5-star cases are the only thing that's really challenging. The Homicide section is easily the best part of the game, really enjoyed it (You solve homicides, duh.) Just above-average as a free-world/sandbox game, most collectibles are just too hidden on a very well depicted L.A., it is interesting because there's about 50 references to classic noir movies, but none of them are (or seem to be) related to where they are placed in the game map, and very uninteresting to look for. Seems like they pieced a really good detective game with modern game elements, kind of a game design flaw but you should still get it for the unique game experience.

reviewText: This is yet another masterpiece of a game delivered by Rockstar. The addition of 'real' facial expressions may seem a bit gimmicky but is essential when questioning suspects. It is up to the game player to determine whether suspects are telling the truth or lying, and this can be done by carefully watching facial expressions. However, if you accuse a suspect of lying you will need to have some kind of proof to back it up. Graphically, the developers has done an amazing job - there does not seem to be a noticable repetition of buildings within the map. Vehicles are rendered beautifully and appear to be fairly faithful to the real things. It is a shame that the game is limited to 30fps on the PC but it is a solid 30fps (played with Fraps running to check). The XBox 360 version has moments where the FPS drops well below 30. Sound is used very well, using a dramatic score when something important is happening in the game. Music is also used during the searching of clues and helps the game player stay within the 'search area'. NPCs have dialogue but it can be quite repetitive. Sound effects are spot on, even down to the sound of aircraft flying high up overhead and chirping birds, etc.\n\nL.A. Noire will appeal to gamers who like to think and solves clues. It may appear to be similar to the GTA series but the missions are in no way similar. If you are an arcade game fan this game will not appeal as it is very difficult to pick it up for a quick blast.

reviewText:
First off let me begin with saying how amazing the storyline in this game is. You start off as a LAPD officer named Cole Phelps a former 1st Lt. in the U.S. Army that fought in WWII. All the cases are believable and could all happen in real life. When you interrogate people it feels so real. Even though you can tell when someone is lying you have to show proof how you know they're lying through the clues you have found throughout the case. The gameplay mechanics are also beautiful and the game runs smooth, except for a couple of glitches. Ex: A lady waitress glitched inside of me while I was sitting down and her ♥♥♥ was in my face while I was interrogating someone at a club. This definitely gets on the top of my list for best RPG games.

Plot 9.5/10
Mechanics 9/10
In total I'd rate this game a 9/10

reviewText: After 40 hours of gameplay time I have to say LA Noire is one of the most ambitious, most interesting and most exciting games I have played in recent years. Attention to detail is top-notch as we have already gotten used to it when it comes to a Rockstar game. But here this is more commendable as this is now a serious" game - you follow the story of detective Phelps
recommended: who rises from being a simple patrolman to working with the best and most influential cops in the force. You quickly realise that there are people harder to catch out there - you start with the small fish only to find clues as to how to grab the biggest sharks in town.\n\nGameplay-wise LA Noire is a bit different from GTA IV. The missions - or as they're referred to
hoursPlayed: cases - usually start out with a crime scene investigation. You get in a car and drive to your destination where you need to look for clues. Clues are objects you can interact with - once you approach one you'll hear a chime; this is how the game tells you that you can now press a button to grab the object in your vicinity. The more clues you find the more are added to your notebook. There is usually a witness around you can interview.\n\nAnd this is the 2nd most important thing in gameplay: interviewing means that while you can pick your questions from a list provided you also need to "evaluate" the suspects' responses. You have 3 options: you either believe what they are saying
voteText: you can remain in doubt or you can shout at them calling them liars. Picking the correct answer will make it easier for you to find and apprehend the real suspect. Make no mistake: if you are wrong it does not mean game over but it will affect the scoring at the end of your case.\n\nYou should also note two more things: firstly
helpfulPercent: you can have help in the form of intuition points. The more crimes you solve the more experience points you get. Once you level up you gain an intuition point. These can be used to remove one of the 3 possible answers thereby increasing your chances to 50%.  Secondly
votesHelpful: once you accuse someone of lying you need to prove that. Phelps immediately turns the page in his notebook to the list of evidences. You need to pick the right evidence to succeed (that is
votesTotal: if you have found enough clues for that to appear in your list).\n\nInterestingly
votesFunny: some of these conversations can be the most exciting and rewarding parts of the game. Rockstar employed a special motion capture technique which makes all faces and expressions as realistic as possible. In fact
commentsCount: you can see the faces of real life actors and actresses - those of you watching a lot of TV series will easily be able to recognise some of these. This also means that voice acting is provided by the same people and it is of equally high quality. Suspects not telling the truth usually look away
column16: move their mouths
column17: grimace
column18: scratch their head
column19: loose their tie
column20: etc.\n\nThe mechanics for the action scenes are similar to that of GTA IV. You have the same cover system
column21: you can brawl occasionally and you have car chases where your partner does the shooting. You just need to make sure you are as close to the suspect's vehicle as possible so that your detective partner can shoot the tires. Sometimes
column22:
your job is to apprehend a suspect in a non-lethal way - if not by brawling then by running after and tackling him. These scenes can get very repetitive which I did not mind in particular - except some of them felt a little too scripted: I thought I could get a guy if I was quick only to realise he was meant to be stopped by an accident.

Another minor annoyance is the interview part: sometimes you are convinced the suspect is lying. You know you do not have any evidence so you pick the option "Doubt" but it turns out the guy was right so he was probably making a grimace due to being confused. As the game has an auto-save function you can easily quit and reload to try again but after a while this can be annoying. It just feels that Rockstar had a certain idea in mind for these choices and if you are lucky you can get the answer right.

But what is there beside the cases you work on? Does LA Noire offer you the option of free roaming? I am happy to say it does: dispatch informs you of ongoing crimes and you can leave your current case to pursue these. Also
column23: there are TONS of items to look for: badges
column25: film reels and 95 (!) vehicles to get into. Once you get into a car it is "unlocked". Under "Extras" in the main menu you'll find a showroom to have a look at an already unlocked vehicle. Many look pretty similar but they can be different models - sometimes it feels a bit ridiculous to get in and out of every vehicle you find in a parking lot but there's no other way for you to find all of them. I have to admit I could only collect 90% of them.\n\nAs for the cases: you have everything you need. Narcotics
column31: etc. The places you visit are varied and look realistic. Accompanying music and sound effects also represent an excellent quality.\n\nLA Noire has 21 cases. It feels as if you were watching a season of your favourite crime series. 21 episodes of it. And when it is over you are happy but at the same time you are eager to see what's coming in the next season. I wish LA Noire had one more season."

reviewText:
The atmosphere in the game is great. Music, cars, scenery, clothing, you really get a feel for the time period. The start of each new chapter gives the feel of a new episode of a crime drama on TV. This is a good fit, as the game is quite a bit like an interactive movie.

The game controls are a bit like Bully (also from Rockstar). Grand Theft Auto controls would have been better, but the game plays perfectly fine with a controller.

The graphics are quite good. The latest and greatest lighting and textures may not be present, but the game does a great job with facial expressions. This is a good thing, as most of the game revolves around your ability as a detective to identify when someone is not telling the truth.

Gameplay has youin the role of a detective. You look for evidence, question suspects and in your off time" run down street criminals as sort of little mini missions.
The evidence searches are quite easy if you set the controller to vibrate when they are nearby. Without the aid of vibration
date: it would be very easy to miss a clue without clicking every shred of paper you walk close to.\nSuspect interviews are a little tougher. You ask a question and get an answer. Then you have to  decide on facial expressions (shifting eyes
hoursPlayed: looking away...etc. if the suspect if not giving the full story
voteText: or if they are flatout lying. If you choose correctly
helpfulPercent: you are rewarded with more information and some points. Choose wrong
votesHelpful: and you will fail to be promoted.\nThere are intuition points you earn that can help to find evidence and determine if someone is lying
votesTotal: but you can burn though these quickly and will need to solve more crimes to refill your suply.\n\nThere are fight scenes with guns and fists
votesFunny: and chase scenes in vehicles. If you fail these smaller missions several times in a row
commentsCount: the game shows you merry and allows skipping the mission without penalty.\n\nAs I said
column16: the game is very much a story that you are taking part in. Gameplay is not very difficult
column17: and while you can replay missions to do better
column18: the story and cutscenes do not really make for interesting replay value.\n\nI'm enjoying the story
column19: and am intrigued enough to keep going. Overall the game is good. I think the only downside is a low replay value.\nThere is some type of online social component to the game
column20: but I've not been able to connect to it
column21: The game is a few years old
column22: so maybe the servers have been shutdown?\n"

reviewText:
this game was excellent, it's largely something unlike the majority of game experiences i've had. I really enjoyed the interrogation mechanics and the use of the motion capture technology for the actors faces to be realistically portrayed in the game was just awesome.

the game loses some steam right after the early sections, it becomes sort of repetitive and the action sequences (driving and shooting sections) are spaced out a little too far for a few hours of gameplay, but make it through this slower section and the game's story and action pick up and hook you into the experience hard enough to push through to the more exciting final chapters of the game.

I experienced a few minor technical issues - mostly with the controls at certain sections of the game, navigating tighter spaces when looking for clues can be a bit clunky and the cover shooting mechanics felt very unpolished and I tended to avoid using the cover system because of that.

9.5/10 experience overall. Had the pacing been a little better in the second act of the game, and the control issues not been there it could've been a 10/10. These two small issues didn't keep me from loving the game regardless though. Probably a top 10 game of all time for me.

get it now

reviewText:
Another Rockstar so immersion is outstanding, again play with headphones.  The feel of, I'm guessing, 1950s LA is tremendous and is really remeniscent of LA Confidential, so I instantly loved this.

The voice acting is really well done indeed and I'm guessing the actors bodies were imaged for each character in this, so it's a big bravo on that.  The story is very impressive and it was excellent to see the main plot ticking over in the background whilst you're following a meandering path, which will eventually lead you to said plot.  The graphics and sound effects were excellent and joined with the innovative element of interrogation you have a winning formula that deserves to be a big fan favourite.  Also hats off to attention to detail with the vehicles.  They had no crumple zones and such in those days, as they were just girders on wheels and if you hit something you really hit it with a crunch.

If you don't have this then get it.

9/10

reviewText:
At one point early on in the game, the protagonist is an officer on the beat walking in the streets of L.A when gunshots are heard from about a block away. There's a body on the sidewalk, paramedics on scene, a few witnesses to question and clues to gather. This is bulk of the gameplay for L.A noire and it is done well. The game also has you interrogarting suspects, driving around town and even the odd car chase.

What I enjoyed was trying to piece together evidence and testimonies. The graphics, while good are somewhat strange when it comes to facial expressions which is annoying when trying to read faces and decide what the next line of interrogation should be. But for the rest its all a solid game. Beautiful heavy ornate cars that handle like the tanks they were. Challenging but not frustrating difficulty. Nice, if slightly forgettable score. And above all a lengthly campaign that doesn't feel repetitive or boring

I recommend this! Especially to people who enjoyed Mafia or GTA or even Pheonix Wright; its an entertaining blend that will keep you on your crime solving toes.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire, you get an insight in post-war America, filled with interesting missions which can correspond with your personality. The game captures your attention with its in game choices, which makes you feel in control of the story. Personally I believe it is easily a classic, and not many other games offer the role of the police but rather the criminal.

Pros
Rockstar Classic
You get to decide your actions
You assume the role of the Police (unusual)
A standalone game
Different Plot
Progression through ranks
Varied Cases

Cons
You cannot be corrupt
Depending on Operating System can lag
Evidence is not always easy to find
At points it can be difficult to follow story, if you do not pay sufficent attention


Definately would recommend this, a must have classic.

reviewText: A game in the style of old detective comics.  It's more of a cerebral game than an action packed one (though there is some action).  The game does kind of drag on at parts, and as such, I highly recommend skipping all the random street crimes, and just having your partner drive you everywhere (by holding down the enter vehicle button until you tell your partner to drive).  The street crimes don't add much to the game unless you're a staunch completionist.  The game is broken up into distinct chapters, and so it is easy to sit down and play it in hour long chunks, which might be nice for some people.\n\nYou can probably get 30ish hours out of this game, but as I said, the game does definitely drag on at points.  I'd recommend it if you see it on sale, but maybe not for full price.  It's a fun game overall, but suffers from the pacing.

reviewText:
I powered through L.A. Noire because I enjoyed the story and I found each case to be compelling.  The way it weaved the past into current events and tied things together by the end was legendary.  The way the devs captured the actor's facial expressions, while treading into the uncanny valley big-time, gave this game an amazing quality.  Driving through old time Los Angeles was a lot of fun.  I think this is a game most people will enjoy.

All that being said sometimes when characters talk their mouths look really wrong.  It looks like the mesh is the wrong shape for the expression ( usually noticable with yelling and other large mouth shapes).  While historically accurate all the cars look way too much alike to necessate the diversity in this game (especially with the frustrating achievement attached to driving them all).  Getting in and out of cars takes flippin' forever.  Special cars that boast a max speed of 140 MPH even at full throtle the game says your max speed even was around 86 MPH.

The main gameplay element of interrigation is frustrating as they purposefully designed it to not allow you to restart a bad interrigation over without quitting and reloading your last save.  Sure, it opens other opportunities to play through the mission based on failure to catch the person in a lie but that wasn't what I was playing this for.

Story gripes ahead, Spoilers: The love interest in this game looks like a dirty bag of melted action figures so when Cole started persuing her romatically I didn't buy it for a second.  You are a war hero get a woman that is worth the trouble. The ending was purposefully unsatisfying but come on give a guy some hope that Cole's work wasn't for nothing.

reviewText:
The atmosphere in the game is great. Music, cars, scenery, clothing, you really get a feel for the time period. The start of each new chapter gives the feel of a new episode of a crime drama on TV. This is a good fit, as the game is quite a bit like an interactive movie.

The game controls are a bit like Bully (also from Rockstar). Grand Theft Auto controls would have been better, but the game plays perfectly fine with a controller.

The graphics are quite good. The latest and greatest lighting and textures may not be present, but the game does a great job with facial expressions. This is a good thing, as most of the game revolves around your ability as a detective to identify when someone is not telling the truth.

Gameplay has youin the role of a detective. You look for evidence, question suspects and in your off time" run down street criminals as sort of little mini missions.
The evidence searches are quite easy if you set the controller to vibrate when they are nearby. Without the aid of vibration

Most games compete in certain brackets and standarts, so their flaws and advantages are defined compared to those that are similar. That means that games which don't fit into those regulations should be judged differently. L.A. reviewText:
L.A. Noire is a game with a lot of backstory in development and otherwise. All you really need to know is that on PC the game has been tremendously upgraded in the visuals. 4K native and 4xSGSSAA make a completely different experience to the PS3 version. This cannot be overstated.

Otherwise, we don't have the upgraded audio from PS3 but basically everything else in one cheap package. Going back to the PS3 version on the DS3 pad is exponentially worse than something like a DS4 and Input Mapper. These two major changes make the PS3 version all but unplayable in retrospect.

For the game, of course, we have old L.A. modelled with exquisite outer detail. The indoor locations are lacking outside of the story mode, and there isn't a lot to do in the city overall. However, if you just take this for what it is the game shines for the time you play it. The Lie-Doubt-Truth mechanic is average, but you can still have fun with the game despite its flaws because being in 1940s L.A. is just honestly kind of fun. The audio is top notch work for the most part. Animations in the faces hold up because of the work they put into it, though, that does hamper the port at aonly 30FPS.

Travelling by cars is pretty fun, and also finding all the different makes and models is actually very cool now that the graphics have proper AA and detail. Most of what you get out of this game depends on if you like the setting. The stories and characters are for sure a cut above the average crowd, and some of them are very well done. But it comes back down to if you like this period and if you have the PC to play it right. An OC'd 970 and 2500K should do the job.

So it's worth it just to see the detail of the city and the 1940s. The artists here pull it all off with great abandon. So much detail was drawn into this city, and yes it is a shame there is not more to do. Sometimes development hell gets the best of you. Still, the stories are interesting enough and the locations all now look so much more lovely than they ever did. Travel around and chill out with L.A. Noire and you'll have a fun time.

The game has an amazing representation of 40's los angeles, with amazing replicas like the great chinese theater and the iconic hollywoodland sign ( now shortend to hollywood ) that also has many npc's that do daily tasks such as walking to work, and reading the daily news paper. If that werent enough, the story, and especially the characters, are amazing and detailed, the facial animation made through motion capture technology is stunning and is beyond its time even in todays standerds. And lastly, the puzzle elements are extremly well done, with very well placed evidence to collect that is used for questioning suspects, to the mind bendingly well done facial expressions, that usually have me stare at my screen intensely as i determine if the suspect is telling the truth, hiding information, or straight up lying to my face. Overall, this game is an AMAZING experience, and reminds me how far a video game can immerce me into a living, breathing, world, right in my computer screen. Thank you for reading.

reviewText:
L.A. Noire is one of those games that can really surprise you with how good it is.

While it has some open world aspects to it, the game is actually quite linear as far as mission structure and story are concerned. This is not a bad thing. It's like watching an old mystery movie, combined with point-and-click game concepts, and GTA mechanics and gameplay. It all fuses together to form a unique game that is very interesting to play through.

The visuals are quite good, and even today could be mistaken for next-gen quality. The faces are very expressive, much more so than most games in general. This is because part of the game is about reading your subject when interrogating them to see if they are lying or not.

While the different elements of this game are derivative from many games you've probably played before, the experience and setting make this a game feel unique. It is certainly worth the playthrough for just about any gamer.

7/10 Good""

reviewText:
The game is a bit strange, to be honest. Not just because it’s not the classic “runny gunny” variant of Rockstar games, but mostly because I have solved 4 or 5 cases and it feels like I haven’t really done much. I’ve unlocked outfits that look like repaints of the same basic thing (Watch_Dogs would later come to have the same exact problem), and I seem to be unlocking intuition points I don’t really need since I can just Shift+Tab to a guide that tells me when people are lieing.

I don’t want to sound like a mouthbreather who can’t handle not having violence in my face every ten minutes. But after 3 hours and two gunfights, I feel there should be a /little/ more peppered around.
My very first case I failed immediately when the perp ran away. I went to fire at him, just once, and actually managed to hit him in the leg. Instant “You failed” screen, “Man got injured” it said. No kidding? He was fleeing.

So I find a street crime a little later, THINKING I shouldn’t be shooting the masked perp with a firing gun. Since I couldn’t figure out how to melee with my gun drawn, I just tried rushing him. Mission failed. “Officer down” it says.
Christ, make up your mind.

Another street crime was a more clearcut gunfight, which was enjoyable but the game CLEARLY didn’t emphasize the gunplay. The controls were a bit sluggish as my dude slowly gets out of cover and slowly figures out that I’m holding the shift button to sprint to a different piece of cover. I haven’t died yet, but I have taken a few shots because Cole won’t move his friggn’ ♥♥♥.

I will admit, first impressions were pretty decent. They’ve taken a slight (but only slight) dip due to the clunky movement. I also don’t feel like an “open ended” game is the right platform for the investigative style it’s going for. Indeed, it’s hardly open ended at all. I can’t really “stop” any investigation and wander. Sometimes my police car gets a call that I can generally divert and deal with, but there’s no ‘wandering’ available. I’m wondering why the world is this large when all I can do is “Investigation” and “shoot some Mexicans over here”. Even clothing is changed via the menu, no shopping to be done.
Is a more open world “unlocked” later? Rockstar is sometimes fond of that. If so, that’s fair. I’ll keep playing it (though mostly in one-hour chunks so my computer doesn’t explode).

reviewText: L.A Noire delivers an exceptional story focusing on the exploits of a WWII officer turned detective in post-WWII L.A. The game efficiently blends story within story (past and present), via chapters that seamlessly blend together, efficiently creating a believable narration of one mans journey though a troubled time, and a troubled country. The game boasts amazing facial animation techniques, thus creating a greater range of viable facial contortions for the actors to express. The authenticity of the time is expressed in great detail as shown with the vehicle designs, the setting of the city, the music, and the people. The game boasts an extremely interactive environment in the form of interrogations, crime solving, clue searching (all being core aspects of gameplay), and in a most realistic way. Vehicular chases of any sort are exhilarating and finely executed (as well as the pedestrian chases), although general movement is a tad clunky, and unfortunately the combat mechanics are relatively mediocre, if fluent and stable. In conclusion: L.A Noire is well worth your time and your money, and is a must have for any fan of the mystery/thriller genre.

reviewText:
Getting right into the end game now. Have actually really enjoyed LA Noire. The stories and characters are very believable - very maturely presented - and the facial animation is absolutely outstanding. There is a tendency for the formulaic which is fairly unavoidable with most games of this nature (drive here, find clues, interview her, next location, gun battle, etc). However I've been kept engaged both with interest in the story and the general challenge level of the game.

Of particular note I've found the loving recreation of 1940's Los Angeles most intriguing. The sense of place and time is absolutely outstanding and well worth the investment. For achievement hunters, the achievements are reasonably constant and offer a good challenge with a handful that only the most dedicated will reach.

Recommend it.

reviewText:
Basically GTA for the faint of heart

Pros
-Unique Gameplay
-Cool Technology used to make it, Motion Scan Techonology
-Some Replay Value
-Dark and Twisted Story
-Open World (-ish)
-Over 30 hours of gameplay
-Feels like a movie
-Noir feel to the game
-Game takes a long time to finish, so alot of gameplay delivered
-Dark but sometimes funny writing
-Collectables
-Strong Voice Acting
-Can get multiple people playing in this game since they can discuss about which choice to pick during an interrogation
-Vehicles all drive differently
-Made by Rockstar :)

Cons
-Not like GTA or Max Payne, you play as a good cop, you must obey the law
-Game randomly throws twists at you mid-game which don't feel clever or shocking
-During the Arson desk, it destorys everything it has done to build up to an conclusion
-Some of the driving parts, i just gave it to my partner because some parts the place you go is the other side of town
-Cars won't drive out of the war when your siren is activated
-Ending, made me sad but still it is a rockstar game so what do you expect?

Overall, L.A. noire is a must play, you'll probably never play a game like this for a while or until they release a sequel. The feel to the game is truly unique and makes me click launch L.A. Noire every time I go onto steam. Even though parts of the game are delivered weak, majority of it outshine the cons therefore making the cons not really not that big of a deal. Even though the ending for me was a let-down, overall I loved the game and wanna play it again.

Rating: MUST BUY!
Final Verdict: 10/10

Yes,yes there are cons in this game, alot of em but this is one of the only games that I actually WANT to finish. Normal games I play for 10 mins then just never come back again but not this game. I actually WANT to play this game and I regret nothing paying money for this game. You may think I am over-rating it but if you look at my gamelist, tell me how many games have I actually finished?

reviewText:
This game tickled me in all of the right places.  I love the period setting (40's, post war), the motion capture (using MotionScan) of facial expressions, the cars, the story...it all worked for me.
A brief mention of a technical detail is necessary however.  The game is capped at 30 FPS and this can result in some performance degradation.  You'll read numerous complaints about it being a console port and that it's unplayable.  True it is a port, but unplayable?  That is completely unfounded.

Now that we've gotten that out of the way...

If you're a fan of film noir and the crime thrillers of yore, you will enjoy this game.  It is not even necessary for you to be particularly good at gaming to complete a play through.  While there is action woven into the cases, most of the time you're putting the pieces together or interviewing suspects.  Some cases had me stumped at times, but I found that all the more encouraging to examine the evidence, make connections and solve it.
My recommendation to anyone considering playing this game, don't be tempted to find a walkthrough to breeze through the cases on auto-pilot.  Give them an honest try and use what's given to you. Games have boundaries so use that to your advantage to make your deductions.  You won't regret it and when you get that 5 star rating at the close of the case, you'll start believing you're ready to join local law enforcement (I jest).
I have to emphasize the MotionScan technology used to capture facial expressions.  This was a necessary and very impressive component to the game.  While interviewing suspects you have to examine their facial expressions and behavior to determine if they are lying or telling the truth.  It is impressive...I don't think enough people give the studio credit for this achievement.

Story wise, I was intrigued by the fact that the story emphasized the impact of WW2.  I don't want to talk about the story too much as to give anything away. The actors casted for the characters were believable and well played.  I started looking them up on IMDB to see where I recognized them from.  In some ways it made me long for the days of FMV in the late 90's but I really loved the style and animation as it stood.  I read that in a potential sequel (not a direct sequel) to LA Noire, they may be working on doing full body motion capture with the MotionScan technology rather than just facial expressions.

To further highlight how much I enjoyed this game, I even embarked upon completing the achievements and gophering around collecting all of the cars and film reels.

Do yourself a favor, give this one a run.

reviewText:
LA Noire is a game that completely nails the gumshoe detective atmosphere but loses a bit on the overall narrative.

Each case is about 1.5-2 hours long, and replayability is non-existant if only because by the time you finish the game you're tired of the simplistic mechanics. By simplistic mechanics" I'm referring to the GTA style driving- and shooting-mechanics.

Aside from that
date: the meat of the game is in detecting people's reactions to your pointed questions. The ability to see a doctor put his hands behind his back and suck on his lower lip as a telegraph that he isn't telling the truth is something that is very difficult to pick up at first but once you get the hang of it you start to really appreciate the development work that went into making it more about sussing out liars and cheaters than about reaction time and purchased upgrades. This game comes highly recommended also because of the way it draws you into post-WW2 Los Angeles: a city that is exploding with the popularity of movies and the pursuit of the american dream.\n\nThe connecting narrative involving the eventual conspiracy scenario really didn't do too well to provide a driving force from case to case. The villains in the game seem very static and aren't fleshed out too well. As a result
recommended: actually finishing the game took some determination because you really don't care by the end.\n\nThat being said
hoursPlayed: I highly recommend playing this game which is now super-cheap in 2014. There are quite a few memorable experiences in it and the concept and execution of the atmosphere is well-worth it."

reviewText:
Just as advertised, playing this game feels like going through a serious of noir films full of action and drama.

You have to hand it to the developers, the facial animations in this game is unlike everything you have ever seen, the characters in this game, regardless of how small his/her role is, are all done with the most top notce animation and voice acting that are just incredibly fun to watch. The gameplay itself, however, lacks the consistent quality in the animations. While at the beginning most of the cases are creative and fun, towards the end you start seeing more and more recurring themes and events that takes outo the freshness of the game. The city, while big, also felt a bit hollow as there aren't really much going on at any given time.

Overall I'd give this game an 8/10, a truly refreshing entry in modern gaming

reviewText: L.A Noire delivers an exceptional story focusing on the exploits of a WWII officer turned detective in post-WWII L.A. The game efficiently blends story within story (past and present), via chapters that seamlessly blend together, efficiently creating a believable narration of one mans journey though a troubled time, and a troubled country. The game boasts amazing facial animation techniques, thus creating a greater range of viable facial contortions for the actors to express. The authenticity of the time is expressed in great detail as shown with the vehicle designs, the setting of the city, the music, and the people. The game boasts an extremely interactive environment in the form of interrogations, crime solving, clue searching (all being core aspects of gameplay), and in a most realistic way. Vehicular chases of any sort are exhilarating and finely executed (as well as the pedestrian chases), although general movement is a tad clunky, and unfortunately the combat mechanics are relatively mediocre, if fluent and stable. In conclusion: L.A Noire is well worth your time and your money, and is a must have for any fan of the mystery/thriller genre.

reviewText: Many people think that L.A. Noire is something like Mafia but they are wrong. Those games have common only the age of story maybe. The biggest difference is in the adventure part of L.A. Noire, you'll have to find evidences and to speak with suspect people mostly in the gameplay. Though shootouts aren't frequent (just in optional missions and at the end of the game) and if you get to some they are boring, the investigations of cases are seriously funny and the system of dialogs is great. You have to decide, if suspect person says truth or lies at the moment. If you choose a lie, you must prove your contention by the appropriate evidence that you have found. You can make a pressure per person as well, if you are not sure. The storyline is higher than average and the surroudings of the City of Angels is very nice. I recommend to buy DLC's as well, there are the best cases in my opinion.

reviewText: I remember an argument when this game came out that Cole Phelps was a weak character because his actions seemed unlikeable and his character was definately flawed. We see him throughout the game being torn down by his own past , we no longer see him cling to the ivory tower of hypocrisy we saw him in, in the beginning of the game. Playing as Jack Kelso at the end is supposed to make us feel like we made a mistake judging Phelps too early because Kelso is a character who is way too nice and lets others trample over him just so he can call himself an honorary man who lives for a higher purpose. But after the ending, you realize that Phelps was right to abandon his fortune for his passion, that there is no higher purpose but to live with what you want out of life and to chase what you want with reckless abandon. His mistake was joining the marines with this mentality and getting most of his men killed in battle and many more civilians killed. In the end, Elsa healed Cole but when let his guard down, he got the retribution he deserved not for commiting adultery but commiting an act of hubris that led to a long and winding path of death and misery. If you think about it this way, Cole was the suspect the whole time, becasue his warcrimes led to most of the game's murder cases.

reviewText:
Never do you play a game that has no clones, or at least not as good as it. That game is L.A. Noire.

Lets look at the Pros, Mixed, and Cons.

+ Very fun gameplay. I want to let you know that this game IS a puzzle game, but not as you might expect. You have to find certain clues, not doing any stupid pushing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It's very fun and addictive, and wants me to have more of it. Also, there is some shooting and driving involved. However, if you wanted this to be a GTA in 1940, then you will be disappointed. However, you should love it, even if puzzles are not your thing.

+ The Sound if FANTASTIC. If I had to rate this game on Sound, it would be a 10.5/10. It's that DAMN GOOD. The soundtrack is great and so 1940s! In fact, I noticed a lot of music from Fallout 3 in here, which also has awesome music. The voice acting is also perfect. It sounded like it could have been real detectives.

+ The graphics are pretty dang sweet. The character models, especially their faces, are great. I never noticed bad lip-syncing, unlike most other games. I know there is one issue invloving graphics, but I will later address that in the review.

+ A long story. It took me around 24 hours to beat L.A. Noire, and I was not rushing. It's fantastic well it lasts. However, well it lasts.

+ Side Missions. They are not that good, but not bad either. It is nice that they added this, so this will not go against the review.

Mixed:
- 30 FPS capped. This would be a huge con IF it were not for a damn good explanation. So, this game was originally a console game, just like Red Dead Redemption (By the way rockstar, add it onto Steam. I don't care that it's almost 5 years old, I really want to play it) As we know, a lot of console games are locked at 30 FPS (Destiny, Fallout 4, etc.) However, Rockstar noticed there was a huge problem. The lip-syncing on PC was not good at all. They had a total of 4 choices: 1. Let there be bad lip-syncing, removing points from the PC review. 2. Redo THE ENTIRE GAME FOR PC, which could have taken a long time. 3. Make the gameplay 60 FPS, but the faces 30 FPS, possibly making bad lag, as well as confusing most people. 4. Keep it the same, but face there will be only be regular players who will outrage. I think 4 was the safest bet, plus it does not run that bad. At 30 FPS, it is fantastic. However, I still wish there was at least an option.

Cons:
- The gameplay gets boring a bit fast. After the 30th time of having a shoot out, it gets tiring. However, only the shooting. The interviews and car driving never get old.

- This game has glitches, which might not seem bad, until I tell you. Screen-tearing, graphical glitches, and more are only uncommon, not rare.

- Very little replay value. There is no second route, like GTA, Fallout, or Elder Scrolls. The next time you play it, it will be the same, which makes it boring. However, there is DLC if you can not get enough, which you would have to be crazy to not be.

FINAL VERDICT

9/10
L.A. Noire is a fantastic game.
At full price it is worth it. On sale, you would have to be crazy not to buy it. I love this game and am praying that Rockstar will make a sequel, improving the games flaws.

reviewText:
We're talking about classic Rockstar Games Hi-Quality merchandise here :)
L.A. Noire is an amazingly new and fresh concept, in a market that only tries to repeat itself.
L.A. Noire is an investigative game in which you are brought to solve many interesting cases as a L.A.P.D. detective.
The cases are varied and amazingly well written, ranging from Traffic cases, to Arson cases, ending with Homicide and Vice.
From time to time, while you solve these cases, you have to perform other tasks like shootouts or car chases ecc...so the game keeps things interesting for the player.
The best feature of the game is the connection you enstablish with the main character.
It's not just a linear progression of cases to solve, but you actually follow the intriguing story of the main character Cole Phelps, and all the cases are all connected into a hidden understory which is very engaging.
The topics that are dealt with are different, but the atmosphere reminds of L.A. Confidential.
The overall graphics are pretty good and the game features a groundbraking facial animation technology which feels strange at first, but then delivers some of the most realistic facial expressions seen in a game, and the best thing is that they are not just for show, they are very important for the gameplay, since you have to check suspects facial expressions (even the smallest details) during interrogations, to spot if they are lying or not.
The Los Angeles reconstruction is incredible; the city is ENORMOUS! It almost feels life-size.
The player is immersed in a very realistic and detailed representation of the most glamorous city in the world (L.A.), in its prime time (the 1940s, after the war).
A great experience, and if you are a patient player you'll be rewarded with one of the best games available on the market.

Pros:
- The Main Character, which is more multi-layered and constructed than it might look at the beginning
- Amazing cases; the developers had great ideas for every case, and you feel engaged to discover the truth
- Varied experience (The case-solving is alternated with other activities)
- Brilliant interrogations system (you need to take care of the clues and the interrogated person's facial expressions)
- L.A. is detailed and beautiful
- Engaging story, linking all the cases togheter
- Long game

Cons:
- There's a bit of aliasing, even if you activate antialiasing
- Needs a patient player to be appreciated and completed (Not a negative point, but it's just to let you know)
- The city is BIG...maybe too big, and some driving phases are a bit boring

Recommended!

reviewText:
After beating this game, you will miss this game.

Story: (9/10) Its story (plot) is very good
Gameplay: (8/10) It presents its story very well
Entertainment: (8/10) You can get yourself into the game
Graphics, sounds: (9/10) It's beautiful


LA Noire is noir and, it's a very good one. It's a movie, it's a novel, it's a TV-serie, it's a puzzle, it's a tragedy, it's a fiction, it's the truth.
Playing a sandbox game as a good policeman is something you will get use to easily.
In the beginning you probably will find the game hard to play and have success in; but when you get into it, you will wonder the finale as much as you will wish that it won't end.


Buy it if your rig is enough.*  You don't need to wait for Steam Sales to come.


* LA Noire has average optimisation. It uses constant 30 FPS because of its technology. When/if you get 25- FPS, it may hurt your eyes. Having a recommended system will solve your problem.

reviewText:
Pretty good.  I don't finish many single-player games as I am easily bored, but I finished this one.  The storey keeps you hooked.  It's well worth the cheap price you can get it for these days.  I payed a lot more.

The driving sections are worth it only to hear the banter between the cops.  You can skip them afterwards (although you can find side-missions if you don't).  The city looks nice, but it is largely just for show (you can't interact with much).  The facial motion-capture and acting is the best I have ever seen in a game.  In fact, it's so good that it makes the rest of the character models and environmental graphics look stragely aweful (but they aren't really thad bad!).

If you're reading this, I'd suggest you buy it.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's a quite interesting game with some unique gameplay mechanics and excellent facial animations, but...It is somewhat let down by horrible driving controls that are extremely over sensitive and the cars handle like tanks.
All the movements in general have a really weighty, clunky feel to them, and there are many times when performing simple actions, such as climbing over a wall during a chase fail because you initiate it at slightly the wrong angle. Quite frustrating and difficult to get used to.

The investigation mechanics are the only thing the game really has going for it, and they are great, but I can't help have the feeling that the game would have been a LOT stronger overall if it focused more on that side of things than on crappy gunplay and drawn out driving sequences.

Probably the most irritating thing is that cut scenes are unskippable...So if you restart a case, you have to sit through all of the dialogue, then drive back to the crime scene etc....This is bad in any game, but in a game that relies heavily on story exposition it is pretty unforgivable.

It does have an interesting story as well. Probably worth picking up in a sale if you are interested in the premise, but don't expect an action game, or rewarding gunplay, or enjoyable driving experiences.

reviewText:
Don't even think to compare this game to GTA-series. It's very different from some stpd thug-simulator like Watch_Dogs or GTA.
Playing this game requires you to roleplay a detective of LAPD. Game is very immersive. City outside the buildings is vivid and alive. Graphics and sounds are very good.
Act like a restless and proud detective. Drive retro cars carefully, stop at traffic lights if not in a hurry, embrace the atmosphere of 40's, listen to some flavor music while driving to settle your mind boiling with clues and suspects from current case. Interogate victims and suspects, look carefully and gather clues at crime scenes, don't get shot in firefights and get upperhand at HtH brawls.
Take your part in ongoing plot.
Interogation logic could'be weird at times, but doesn't break immersion or plot. Cases could be solved faster if you ask right questions and find important evidence upfront. This promotes replayability of the game.

Verdict: This game is incredible if played right! Highly recommended.

reviewText:
This game was awesome during the seemingly Tutorial. Everything seemed smart and clueful. But a few missions into the detective game and I am frustrated by trying to get a perfect case in an bull**** rigged question and answer system. In this 'case', I refer to the Ambassador's stolen car The consul's car.

When talking to a witness, you get 3 choices of answers: Truth; Doubt; Lie.
But in this certain case, I doubt the witnessess are telling the truth, and I have no proof he and she are lieing, so I choose doubt. My guy blows his top and calls the witnesses liars, and the game tells me I failed to choose correctly. So I restart the case many times. Finally I chose that the witness is telling the Truth. My guy calmly tells the witness he is lyeing, and the witness confesses and gives more evidence. Game tells me I chose correctly this time. WTF!?!?! This is bull****!!! The two answers are backwards, but are scripted as if it were correct.

This kept happening during this certain case, and I have to wonder if the rest of the cases are also scripted to mess with the player instead of acting correctly. Its so frustrating to be told you are wrong when you were correct, and slapped on the wrist for it, until you answer incorrectly and are rewarded for it.

The fun parts though are the action scenes if you are driving a squad car. You stop for a bank robbery and kill all the bank robbers in 40 seconds. Then you wish there were 10 more bank robbers so you felt it was a challenge. Most of the time there seemed to be 4 bank robbers, but then there were 5 or 6 the last time, so I hope that my level increases the difficulty of the action scenes.

On the downfall, most of the action scenes are incredibly easy. I assume its because I learned the controls really well, but I hope they get incredibly difficult.

The worst part was running the case again forces you to re-live the entire storyline times X. There is no scene skipping, EVER! I looked on the RockStar page and someone asked for a kb key to press to skip scenes and they said backspace, and this was also shown in the control options. But backspace does not work! So... replay 25 minutes of scene footage to get to the part where you ask 3 questions to a witness again. Aaarrgghh!! Now this is frustrating.

I wish it told me what I was going to say before I chose an option. Like:
Truth: I bet you know more than you are letting on.
Doubt: You know you are lieing, tell me the truth!
Lie: You're lieing! I have proof you did it in the lounge with the candlestick!
but... it doesn't. You have to play 25 minutes to see what you are going to say during a questioning.

Cons:Citizens look too much alike. I question one citizen, and in the next case there is another citizen who looks exactly like the previous citizen. I don't get it... in a small town, or a big city, all main characters should look unique. At least change their clothes and their hair.
Backwards choices.
Catching bad guys not involved in your case does not lead to opening new cases against them.
Unlock cars by stealing them. Can't buy them.
No money system. Except for some sort of city damages that doesn't seem to affect you.
Easy action missions.
Can't skip scenes.
Can't skip chatting.
No reason to explore the world if its not involved in your own mission.
Can't use your gun, unless the game makes you take it out. And its not wise to use your gun even when the game forces you to take it out.
Can't pull your fists out, unless the game makes you.
Your guy yells at people on his own. You aren't controlling him. Its a movie, not a game.
Mini-map does not rotate. No options for the mini-map.
Large map takes 2 seconds to load, and 3 clicks to get back to game, which is 8 seconds. This is frustrating since there is no GPS. You are likely to drive into a long tunnel, instead of going towards your destination.
As you play, you realize there is less and less of a reason to explore anything unless it is literally handed to you. (Marked for inspection at the scene by a previous officer.) (Look for shining objects, cause if its not shining then its not ever important.)
Many items to inspect are blocked by other items to inspect, making it hard to inspect even if you know that it is there to inspect. a missing flag on an argentinian ambassador's car is blocked by a missing license plate. This type of clue blocking happens in many cases.
Can't look at your watch in game.
Can't tell what date it is. But many records of the date when someone signed something.Pros:Feeling you are smart when you catch someone in a lie. (If the game feels like being truthful.)
Open world.
Environment feels real, where there are loads of things to look at, but seldom does anything belong to the case you are working on. You get used to this, and stop looking at things that don't belong to any case ever.
Game is set before finger printing, and everyone grabs a gun and fingers the crap out of it no matter what.
Game shows how a police officer can walk right into anyone's house if they are invited inside for a different reason, then beat up the citizen and search his house for any reason what-so-ever. No need for warrants when police are invited inside.
70+ cars to unlock.
Fun (but easy) action missions.
No GPS guidance, because you are in the 1940's.tl;dr
All in all... I feel to answer what you want to answer, you need a walk-through. But this goes against playing the game and sleuthing! Why not just watch a youtube video of this game instead?

If the game had a second tutorial on how to think like the developers thought that investigators should interogate citizens, then this game could have been a ton of fun and a shining star. Otherwise, you are left with writers trying to outsmart a player through cheap tricks.
And by tricks I mean: thinking you Doubt someone, so you say Truth so that you Doubt"."
