reviewText:
I give this game a pass and recommendthat you do too.

Honestly, there's nothing wrong with the game.  Everything is functional and works fine.  It plays well.  The problems for me are twofold: other games have done all of the elements better, and context.

Running is fine, shooting is fine, the sound effects are fine, driving is fine, the open world is fine, interrogations are fine, investigations are fine.  There's nothing particularly wrong with any element and like I said the game is functional.  It works.  It's just that so many other games do everything better.  Pretty much any sandbox -- though most notably GTA -- does almost all of the elements better just because of context alone: it makes sense when you're in a huge gunfight or you're firing randomly at people, or driving like a maniac down the road.  Or, you know, stealing a ♥♥♥♥ing car.  I'm not saying that these events never happen if you're a police officer but I have to scratch my head at the ideas of it.

Interrogations are fine.  They're ok.  They're acceptable.  However, any game in the Turnabout Courtroom series does the interrogation model so much better.  I never thought I would miss saving between interrogations because of life totals, but holy ♥♥♥♥ I do now.  This one and done ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is just aggrivating, especially when the answers are so vague at times (Hi, I'm showing you a blood stained weapon found in your car, in relation to a question about blood all over your car.  Why is this deemed wrong?  And now I'm out of the interrogation).  I get that you can ♥♥♥♥ the interrogations up and your progress isn't stalled but it is frustrating to have so many options before you and see that several could work.  At  least in Turnabout courtroom I'm just slightly perplexed when one of them is wrong, because you know what?  I can keep going and try again.

The open world makes no sense to me.  I don't understand why it was necessary for this game, as a large part of it is just driving from one point to another for story missions.  Sure, on occassion a crime pops up, but you have to accept that as your new mission anyway.  It's not like you drive by and one is going on, and you can take care of it or ignore it.  There's no organic feel whatsoever.

LA Noire does create a very wonderful world that I enjoyed to drive around, it's just that it was hollow.  You know, like the rest of the game.

It took me a few weeks of not playing to decide but I came to the conclusion that I did not want to finish this game.  I'd seen enough of it and felt that, after 6 or so hours, it would just be more of the same.  I'm open to being wrong, and maybe I'll open it up again later and change my mind, but for now I'd rather just play another game.  One that's actually fun and not aggrivating.

reviewText:
L.A Noire

Positives:

+ A very cool and well thought-out detective thriller set in 1940's California, U.S.A. Playing as Coles Phelps you investigate homicides, thefts, drug trafficking and fraud, identifying crime scene clues and speaking to witnesses to gather evidence.
+ A really nice feature of this game is the facial expressions used by characters. A lot of effort was put into this by the developers. After carefully observing how a person of interest behaves or talks, you can doubt what they are saying, judge whether they are lying, or believe them. If you're successful, you'll squeeze more information out of them leading to additional avenues in the case. This is good because it rewards the player for engaging in the game and playing it properly.
+ Nice shootouts with several different types of weapons, although confrontations aren't that frequent. Use tommy guns, pistols or shotguns to take down foes. There's 40 street crimes to complete separate from cases.
+ An intriguing storyline of crime, love and flashbacks of Cole Phelps life in the Marines during World War II. The ending is one you won't really expect. Really enjoyed it.
+ Around 40-50 hours of gameplay with all DLC, trying to do your best on every case.
+ Graphics are decent.


Negatives:

- The graphical quality of the game world could be improved. As it stands it still looks fine, but stunning visuals really do add to immersion.

Overall Score: 9/10

It's hard to fault L.A Noire. This game kept me entertained and had lots of playtime available, the DLC adds some epic firefights and the story was great. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
I've only played through the first campaign and that's a story in itself.  It is a cinematic game akin to Mafia 2 which was an incredible experience.  The fault of this game is the confusing interrogation of the suspects and witnesses.  The whole lie/truth/neutral stance really makes no sense to me whatsoever because whatever I click, Cole's response is never what I expect him to say.  If I knew what he was going to say before I click it would feel so much better and probably give me more correct run throughs.  I also failed to pay attention to some of the characters from the larger story arc but that's my fault so the story campaign was a little confusing.

On the bright side, the shooting and fight mechanics are awesome.  Driving around LA is great fun.  The world looks and sounds brilliant though it does run a little slow on my computer.  The dialogue and character interactions are top notch with excellent voice acting.  The facial expressions are a shining highlight and it makes those interrogations special even if I don't choose the correct option.

Don't get too wrapped up in the interrogations, maybe it's all my fault, but the rest of the game is good enough, especially for 5 bucks on sale.

reviewText: I fully recommend this game, for those who like crime-solving games, games with mystery or suspense, or for those who enjoy the '50s noire detective/gangster theme. I myself enjoy all three of these elements, and so find this game incredibly addictive and enjoyable. The game is designed so that mistakes can be made during clue collecting (ie, you miss a clue) and interrogation (ie, you fail to call out a witness on a lie, or accept a lie as the truth) without a failure-state; it simply makes it more difficult to come to the correct conclusion at the end of the case, or it leads to a decreased score on the case. Each case has a very powerful film noire feel, and the cases are often based on historical cases from the 50s. You play Detective Phelps, an WW2 veteran who has turned to detective work for the LA police, and you interact with diverse, interesting characters, all with great voice acting and motion capture. To sum it up, there's not really any other game like this one, so if it appeals to you, get it! If you get it today, it's on sale for 4.99, but if you get the complete edition for an extra 10 cents, it comes with a couple extra cases and other DLC. What a steal!

reviewText:
Pros:

• Amazing Storyline, watches itself like a Movie
• Very distinctive characters
• Fun Sidequests
• Extremely atmospheric and immersive (cars, radio, fashion, etc)
• Fairly decent Graphics

Cons:

• Practically no Replayability ( except if you want to 5-Star every single Case)
• Painful Driving Mechanics
• No real Openworld

All in all, LA Noire does have its weak points, yet it remains a game that is very fun to play, demands attention and wit, has amusing characters and legitimately funny scenes, and will never fail to captivate you with its great acting and enthralling storyline.
If youre into the Noire Film Genre, definitely check it out. If youre looking for loads of action and FPS Material, LA Noire might not be your thing, but you should try it out regardless.

8,25/10 I am glad to have bought it and loved playing it to death.

reviewText: At a time when narrative in gaming is constantly trying to find its own identity, L.A. Noire does a fine job of giving you the right amount of control amongst the very well acted cutscenes.\n\nThe facial recognition tech hasn't been attempted since, and for good reason. L.A. Noire is constantly ranked amongst the most expensive games ever made - and it shows in the quality of the facial animations. I will say, though, that in large crowd shots, it is quite easy to tell which characters have the facial motion capture and which don't - and the ones that don't (i.e. equivalent of 'extras' in movies and television) do not look very good.

reviewText:
This game is a must for anyone that likes crime drama or detective noir. This is not GTA. GTA is more like Saints Row which are both great games but not much like this game. LA Noire is more like Mafia or Hard Rain set in the post WW2 era but it plays more like a movie. So the equation: ((HR x 2) + M) may be a start.

What the game lacks in action it makes up for in story. It will draw you in -I played it straight through which is unusual for me. While solving the main story mystery there are mini-games/crimes that will show up. Some of the mini crimes tie into the main storyline but are not essential. They are great if you feel the need for some action. There are also cars, badges and film reels scattered about that you can collect in a Free Roam Mode.

The only issue I had was the 30FPS cap on the game which can make the game seem choppy at times but it doesn't ruin the game. This is a great game and I am looking foward to the next installment. I recommend buying all the DLC with this game before you play since it adds so much to the story.
